soln_description:
4. $k<-\frac{1}{9}$.

Obviously, $k \neq 0, x=0$ is a known solution of the equation.
When $x \neq 0$, the condition becomes $|x|(x+6)=-\frac{1}{k}$ having three distinct non-zero real solutions.
From the graph of $f(x)=|x|(x+6)$ (as shown in Figure 6), we get $0<-\frac{1}{k}<f(-3) \Rightarrow 0<-\frac{1}{k}<9$
$\Rightarrow k<-\frac{1}{9}$.
informal_statement: 4. Given the equation about $x$: $k x^{2}+\frac{|x|}{x+6}=0$ has four distinct real solutions. Then the range of the real number $k$ is $\qquad$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 4. Given the equation about $x$: $k x^{2}+\frac{|x|}{x+6}=0$ has four distinct real solutions. Then the range of the real number $k$ is $\qquad$ -/
theorem algebra_199374 (k : ℝ) (h : {x : ℝ | x ≠ -6 ∧ k * x ^ 2 + abs x / (x + 6) = 0}.encard = 4) :
    k < -1 / 9 := by

informal_statement: Find the maximum value of $-x^2 + 12x - 19$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find the maximum value of $-x^2 + 12x - 19$. -/
theorem algebra_6830 (f : ℝ → ℝ) (hf : f = λ x => -x ^ 2 + 12 * x - 19) :
    IsGreatest (Set.image f {x | ∃ t, f t = x}) 17 := by

soln_description:
Solution. If $p=7$, then $3^{p}-2^{p}-1=2187-128-1=2058=42 \cdot 49$.

Let $p>3$ be a prime number different from 7. Then, by Fermat's Little Theorem, $3^{p}-2^{p}-1 \equiv 3-2-1=0(\bmod p)$. Furthermore, $p=6k+1$ or $p=6k+5$ for some $k \in \mathbb{N}$.

If $p=6k+1$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 3^{p}=\left(3^{6}\right)^{k} \cdot 3 \equiv 3(\bmod 7) \text { and } 2^{p}=\left(2^{6}\right)^{k} \cdot 2 \equiv 2(\bmod 7) \\
& 2^{p}=\left(2^{2}\right)^{3k} \cdot 2 \equiv 2(\bmod 3) \text { and } 3^{p} \equiv 3(\bmod 3) \\
& 3^{p} \equiv 1 \equiv 3(\bmod 2) \text { and } 2^{p} \equiv 2(\bmod 2)
\end{aligned}
$$

therefore,

$$
3^{p}-2^{p}-1 \equiv 0(\bmod 7), 3^{p}-2^{p}-1 \equiv 0(\bmod 2) \text { and } 3^{p}-2^{p}-1 \equiv 0(\bmod 3)
$$

However, $2,3,7$ and $p$ are pairwise coprime, so $3^{p}-2^{p}-1 \equiv 0(\bmod 42 p)$.

If $p=6k+5$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 3^{p}=\left(3^{6}\right)^{k} \cdot 3^{5} \equiv 5(\bmod 7) \text { and } 2^{p}=\left(2^{6}\right)^{k} \cdot 2^{5} \equiv 4(\bmod 7) \\
& 2^{p}=\left(2^{2}\right)^{3k+2} \cdot 2 \equiv 2(\bmod 3) \text { and } 3^{p} \equiv 3(\bmod 3) \\
& 3^{p} \equiv 1 \equiv 3(\bmod 2) \text { and } 2^{p} \equiv 2(\bmod 2)
\end{aligned}
$$

therefore,

$$
3^{p}-2^{p}-1 \equiv 0(\bmod 7), 3^{p}-2^{p}-1 \equiv 0(\bmod 2) \text { and } 3^{p}-2^{p}-1 \equiv 0(\bmod 3)
$$

However, $2,3,7$ and $p$ are pairwise coprime, so $3^{p}-2^{p}-1 \equiv 0(\bmod 42 p)$.
informal_statement: 1. If $p$ is a prime number greater than 3, prove that $3^{p}-2^{p}-1$ is divisible by $42p$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. If $p$ is a prime number greater than 3, prove that $3^{p}-2^{p}-1$ is divisible by $42p$. -/
theorem number_theory_231683 (p : ℕ) (hp : Nat.Prime p) (h : 3 < p) :
    42 * p ∣ 3^p - 2^p - 1 := by

soln_description:
30. Answer: $p=17, q=3$.

Let's look at the remainders when dividing by 3, we get $p^{2}+q^{2} \equiv 1(\bmod 3)$, this is only possible if one of the numbers is 3.

Let $q=3$, we get the quadratic equation: $p^{2}-18 p+17=0$. This gives us $p=1$ or 17. 1 is not a prime number, so $p=17$.

Let $p=3$, then $q^{2}-15 q+8=0$. The solutions to this equation are not integers, so they do not fit our criteria.
informal_statement: 30. Solve the equation $p^{2}-6 p q+q^{2}+3 q-1=0$ in prime numbers.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 30. Solve the equation $p^{2}-6 p q+q^{2}+3 q-1=0$ in prime numbers. -/
theorem number_theory_219186 (p q : ℕ) (hp : p.Prime) (hq : q.Prime)
    (h : p^2 - 6 * p * q + q^2 + 3 * q - 1 = 0) : p = 17 ∧ q = 3 := by

soln_description:
Observe that $a_{n+1}-2=a_{n}^{2}\left(a_{n}-2\right)$ for all $n \geq 1$. By induction on $n$ we obtain

$$
a_{n+1}-2=3 a_{n}^{2} a_{n-1}^{2} \cdots a_{1}^{2}
$$

for all $n \geq 1$. Therefore

$$
a_{2014}+1=3\left(a_{2013}^{2} a_{2012}^{2} \cdots a_{1}^{2}+1\right)=3\left[\left(a_{2013} a_{2012} \cdots a_{1}\right)^{2}+1\right]
$$

It is well known that if $q$ is a prime divisor of $x^{2}+1(x \in \mathbb{Z})$ then $q \not \equiv 3 \bmod 4$. (This is a special case of a result known as quadratic reciprocity.) So the $p$ in the problem must be 3 .
informal_statement: Let $a_{1}=5$ and $a_{n+1}=a_{n}^{3}-2 a_{n}^{2}+2$ for all $n \geq 1$. Prove that if $p$ is a prime divisor of $a_{2014}+1$ and $p \equiv 3 \bmod 4$, then $p=3$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $a_{1}=5$ and $a_{n+1}=a_{n}^{3}-2 a_{n}^{2}+2$ for all $n \geq 1$. Prove that if $p$ is a prime divisor of $a_{2014}+1$ and $p \equiv 3 \bmod 4$, then $p=3$. -/
theorem number_theory_258074 (a : ℕ → ℤ)
    (h₀ : a 1 = 5)
    (h₁ : ∀ n ≥ 1, a (n + 1) = a n ^ 3 - 2 * a n ^ 2 + 2) :
    ∀ p, Prime p → p ∣ a 2014 + 1 → p ≡ 3 [ZMOD 4] → p = 3 := by

soln_description:
$$
\text { 1. } \begin{aligned}
f\left(x^{100}\right) & =\left(x^{100}\right)^{99}+\left(x^{100}\right)^{98}+\cdots+x^{100}+1 \\
& =\left[\left(x^{100}\right)^{99}-1\right]+\left[\left(x^{100}\right)^{98}-1\right]+\cdots+\left(x^{100}-1\right)+100 \\
& =\left(x^{100}-1\right) F(x)+100 \\
& =f(x)[(x-1) F(x)]+100,
\end{aligned}
$$

Here $F(x)$ is a polynomial with integer coefficients, so the remainder when $f\left(x^{100}\right)$ is divided by $f(x)$ is 100.
informal_statement: 1. Let $f(x)=x^{99}+x^{98}+\cdots+x+1$, find the remainder when $f\left(x^{100}\right)$ is divided by $f(x)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset Real Polynomial

/- 1. Let $f(x)=x^{99}+x^{98}+\cdots+x+1$, find the remainder when $f\left(x^{100}\right)$ is divided by $f(x)$. -/
theorem algebra_142745 {f : Polynomial ℝ} (hf : f = ∑ i ∈ range 100, X ^ i) :
    (f.comp (X ^ 100)) % f = 100 := by

soln_description:
(1) From the assumption, we get $a_{1}=4, b_{1}=4$. And when $n \geqslant 1$,

Similarly, we can derive
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(2 a_{n}-1\right)+\sqrt{3} b_{n} \\
= & (7+4 \sqrt{3})^{n-1}\left(2 a_{1}-1+\sqrt{3} b_{1}\right) \\
= & (7+4 \sqrt{3})^{n} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly, $\left(2 a_{n}-1\right)-\sqrt{3} b_{n}=(7-4 \sqrt{3})^{n}$.
Thus,
$$
a_{n}=\frac{1}{4}(7+4 \sqrt{3})^{n}+\frac{1}{4}(7-4 \sqrt{3})^{n}+\frac{1}{2} .
$$

Since $7 \pm 4 \sqrt{3}=(2 \pm \sqrt{3})^{2}$,
we have $a_{n}=\left[\frac{1}{2}(2+\sqrt{3})^{n}+\frac{1}{2}(2-\sqrt{3})^{n}\right]^{2}$.
By the binomial expansion,
$$
\begin{aligned}
c_{n} & =\frac{1}{2}(2+\sqrt{3})^{n}+\frac{1}{2}(2-\sqrt{3})^{n} \\
& =\sum_{0 \leq 2 k \leqslant n} C_{n}^{2 k} \cdot 3^{k} \cdot 2^{n-2 k},
\end{aligned}
$$

Clearly, $c_{n}$ is an integer, so $a_{n}$ is a perfect square.
(2) From the given information,
$$
\begin{aligned}
a_{n+1} & =7 a_{n}+6 b_{n}-3 \\
& =7 a_{n}+6\left(8 a_{n-1}+7 b_{n-1}-4\right)-3 \\
& =7 a_{n}+48 a_{n-1}+42 b_{n-1}-27 .
\end{aligned}
$$

From $a_{n}=7 a_{n}-1+6 b_{n-1}-3$, we get
$$
42 b_{n-1}=7 a_{n}-49 a_{n-1}+21 \text {. }
$$

Therefore,
$$
\begin{aligned}
a_{n+1} & =7 a_{n}+48 a_{n-1}+7 a_{n}-49 a_{n-1}+21-27 \\
& =14 a_{n}-a_{n-1}-6 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Given $a_{0}=1=1^{2}, a_{1}=4=2^{2}, a_{2}=49=7^{2}$, let $c_{n+1}=4 c_{n}-c_{n-1}, c_{0}=1, c_{1}=$ $c_{2}=7$, by induction, the sequence $\left\{c_{n} \mid\right.$ is a uniquely determined sequence of positive integers.
Let $d_{n}=c_{n}^{2}$, then
$$
\begin{aligned}
d_{n+1} & =c_{n+1}^{2}=\left(4 c_{n}-c_{n-1}\right)^{2} \\
& =16 c_{n}^{2}-8 c_{n} c_{n-1}+c_{n-1}^{2} \\
& =14 c_{n}^{2}-c_{n-1}^{2}-6-2\left(4 c_{n} c_{n-1}-c_{n}^{2}-c_{n-1}^{2}-3\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

And $4 c_{n} c_{n-1}-c_{n}^{2}-c_{n-1}^{2}-3$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
=4 c_{n} c_{n-1}-c_{n}\left(4 c_{n-1}-c_{n-2}\right)-c_{n-1}^{2}-3 \\
=c_{n} c_{n-2}-c_{n-1}^{2}-3 \\
=\left(4 c_{n-1}-c_{n-2}\right) c_{n-2}-c_{n-1}\left(4 c_{n-2}-c_{n-3}\right)-3 \\
=c_{n-1} c_{n-3} \quad c_{n-2}^{2}-3 \\
=\cdots \cdots=c_{2} c_{0}-c_{1}^{2}-3=0,
\end{array}
$$

Hence, $d_{n+1}=14 d_{n}-d_{n-1}-6, d_{0}=1, d_{1}=4$.
By uniqueness, $a_{n}=d_{n}=c_{n}^{2}, n=0,1,2, \cdots$.
Therefore, $a_{n}$ is a perfect square.
informal_statement:
Sure, here is the translated text:

```
II. (50 points)
Let the sequences $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ and $\left\{b_{n}\right\}$ satisfy $a_{0}=1, b_{0}=0$, and
\[
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
a_{n+1}=7 a_{n}+6 b_{n}-3, \\
b_{n+1}=8 a_{n}+7 b_{n}-4,
\end{array} \quad n=0,1,2, \cdots .\right.
\]

Prove: $a_{n} (n=0,1,2, \cdots)$ is a perfect square.
```
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Sure, here is the translated text:

```
II. (50 points)
Let the sequences $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ and $\left\{b_{n}\right\}$ satisfy $a_{0}=1, b_{0}=0$, and
\[
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
a_{n+1}=7 a_{n}+6 b_{n}-3, \\
b_{n+1}=8 a_{n}+7 b_{n}-4,
\end{array} \quad n=0,1,2, \cdots .\right.
\]

Prove: $a_{n} (n=0,1,2, \cdots)$ is a perfect square.
``` -/
theorem algebra_130425 {a b : ℕ → ℤ} (ha0 : a 0 = 1) (hb0 : b 0 = 0)
    (han : ∀ n, a (n + 1) = 7 * a n + 6 * b n - 3) (hbn : ∀ n, b (n + 1) = 8 * a n + 7 * b n - 4) :
    ∀ n, ∃ m, a n = m ^ 2 := by

informal_statement: Determine all positive integers $n$ for which there exists a positive integer $m$ such that $\frac{4^n - 1}{3}$ divides $49m^2 + 1$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Determine all positive integers $n$ for which there exists a positive integer $m$ such that $\frac{4^n - 1}{3}$ divides $49m^2 + 1$. -/
theorem number_theory_2427 (n : ℕ) :
    n > 0 ∧ ∃ m > 0, (4 ^ n - 1) / 3 ∣ (49 * m ^ 2 + 1) ↔ ∃ k, n = 2 ^ k := by

soln_description:
1. By multiplying both sides of the given equation by four, we get

$$
4 x^{2}+4 y^{2}+4 x+4 y=16 \text {. }
$$

The expression on the left side of the thus modified equation is completed to the sum of the squares of two binomials. We obtain

$$
\left(4 x^{2}+4 x+1\right)+\left(4 y^{2}+4 y+1\right)=(2 x+1)^{2}+(2 y+1)^{2}=18 .
$$

It is therefore sufficient to investigate all decompositions of the number 18 into the sum of two positive odd numbers, since the numbers $2 x+1$ and $2 y+1$ are not divisible by two (and thus do not equal zero) for any integers $x$ and $y$.

Consider, therefore, the following decompositions:

$$
18=1+17=3+15=5+13=7+11=9+9 \text {. }
$$

Among the given sums, only one $(18=9+9)$ is the sum of the squares of two integers. Therefore, the following four cases can occur:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 2 x+1=3, \quad 2 y+1=3, \quad \text { i.e. } x=1, \quad y=1 \\
& 2 x+1=3, \quad 2 y+1=-3, \quad \text { i.e. } x=1, \quad y=-2, \\
& 2 x+1=-3,2 y+1=3, \quad \text { i.e. } x=-2, y=1, \\
& 2 x+1=-3,2 y+1=-3, \quad \text { i.e. } x=-2, y=-2 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Conclusion. The given equation is satisfied by exactly four pairs of integers $(x, y)$, namely $(1,1)$, $(1,-2)$, $(-2,1)$, and $(-2,-2)$.

Alternative solution. The given equation can be rearranged to the form $x(x+1)+y(y+1)=4$, from which it is clear that the number 4 must be decomposed into the sum of two integers, each of which is the product of two consecutive integers. Since the smallest values of the expression $t(t+1)$ for positive and negative integers $t$ are $0,2,6,12, \ldots$, only the decomposition $4=2+2$ is feasible, so each of the unknowns $x, y$ must equal one of the numbers 1 or -2, the only integers $t$ for which $t(t+1)=2$. Moreover, it is clear that each of the four pairs $(x, y)$ composed of the numbers $1,-2$ is a solution to the given problem.

For a systematic and complete solution, award 6 points. For guessing the solution $(1,1)$, do not award any points; for each additional correctly guessed solution, award 1 point; for all correctly guessed solutions, award 2 points. For a correct approach, deduct 1 point for each missing solution. The uniqueness of the decomposition of the number 18 into the sum of two squares is so obvious that it does not need to be justified (as stated in the original solution).
informal_statement:
1. Solve the equation in the domain of integers

$$
x^{2}+y^{2}+x+y=4
$$
informal_proof:
We want to prove that an integer pair \( (x, y) \) satisfies the equation \( x^2 + y^2 + x + y = 4 \) if and only if \( (x, y) \) is one of four specific pairs: \( (1, 1) \), \( (1, -2) \), \( (-2, 1) \), or \( (-2, -2) \). This is an "if and only if" statement, so we must prove both directions.

**Part 1: Forward Implication**
Assume that \( x^2 + y^2 + x + y = 4 \) holds for some integers \( x \) and \( y \). We need to show that \( (x, y) \) must be one of the four listed pairs.

1.  **Establishing Bounds for \( x \) and \( y \):**
    From the given equation, we can deduce constraints on the possible values of \( x \) and \( y \). Using algebraic reasoning and the fundamental property that the square of any real number is non-negative, we establish the following bounds:
    *   **For \( x \):**
        *   We can prove that \( x \geq -3 \). This is derived from the equation \( x^2 + y^2 + x + y = 4 \) combined with the fact that \( (x+2)^2 \geq 0 \) and \( (y+2)^2 \geq 0 \). (For instance, consider \( (2x+1)^2 + (2y+1)^2 = 18 \). Since \( (2y+1)^2 \le 18 \), we have \( (2x+1)^2 \le 18 \), which implies \( -4.24 < 2x+1 < 4.24 \). As \( 2x+1 \) is an integer, \( -4 \le 2x+1 \le 4 \). This leads to \( -2.5 \le x \le 1.5 \), from which \( x \geq -2 \) and \( x \leq 1 \) for integers, which implies \( x \geq -3 \) and \( x \leq 2 \)).
        *   Similarly, we can prove that \( x \leq 2 \), using the equation and the non-negativity of \( (x-1)^2 \) and \( (y-1)^2 \).
    *   **For \( y \):**
        *   Likewise, we can prove that \( y \geq -3 \) using \( (x+2)^2 \geq 0 \) and \( (y+2)^2 \geq 0 \).
        *   And \( y \leq 2 \) using \( (x-1)^2 \geq 0 \) and \( (y-1)^2 \geq 0 \).

    These bounds restrict \( x \) and \( y \) to be integers in the interval \( [-3, 2] \). That is, \( x \in \{-3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2\} \) and \( y \in \{-3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2\} \).

2.  **Exhaustive Case Analysis:**
    Since both \( x \) and \( y \) are restricted to a finite set of integer values, we can perform an exhaustive check of all possible pairs \( (x, y) \). We systematically iterate through each of the six possible integer values for \( x \) from \( -3 \) to \( 2 \). For each choice of \( x \), we then iterate through all six possible integer values for \( y \) from \( -3 \) to \( 2 \). This process generates \( 6 \times 6 = 36 \) distinct integer pairs \( (x, y) \).

    For each of these 36 pairs, we substitute the values of \( x \) and \( y \) into the original equation \( x^2 + y^2 + x + y = 4 \).
    *   If the equation holds for a specific pair \( (x, y) \), then that pair is a solution.
    *   If the equation does not hold for a pair \( (x, y) \), then that pair is not a solution.

    By performing this systematic check, we find that the equation \( x^2 + y^2 + x + y = 4 \) is satisfied only by the following four pairs:
    *   If \( (x, y) = (1, 1) \), then \( 1^2 + 1^2 + 1 + 1 = 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 = 4 \).
    *   If \( (x, y) = (1, -2) \), then \( 1^2 + (-2)^2 + 1 + (-2) = 1 + 4 + 1 - 2 = 4 \).
    *   If \( (x, y) = (-2, 1) \), then \( (-2)^2 + 1^2 + (-2) + 1 = 4 + 1 - 2 + 1 = 4 \).
    *   If \( (x, y) = (-2, -2) \), then \( (-2)^2 + (-2)^2 + (-2) + (-2) = 4 + 4 - 2 - 2 = 4 \).
    All other 32 pairs within the bounds fail to satisfy the equation.

Therefore, if \( x^2 + y^2 + x + y = 4 \), then \( (x, y) \) must be one of these four pairs.

**Part 2: Reverse Implication**
Assume that \( (x, y) \) is one of the four specified integer pairs: \( (1, 1) \), \( (1, -2) \), \( (-2, 1) \), or \( (-2, -2) \). We need to show that \( x^2 + y^2 + x + y = 4 \).

We verify this by considering each of the four cases:

1.  **Case 1: \( (x, y) = (1, 1) \).**
    Substitute \( x = 1 \) and \( y = 1 \) into the equation:
    \( 1^2 + 1^2 + 1 + 1 = 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 = 4 \).
    The equation holds.

2.  **Case 2: \( (x, y) = (1, -2) \).**
    Substitute \( x = 1 \) and \( y = -2 \) into the equation:
    \( 1^2 + (-2)^2 + 1 + (-2) = 1 + 4 + 1 - 2 = 4 \).
    The equation holds.

3.  **Case 3: \( (x, y) = (-2, 1) \).**
    Substitute \( x = -2 \) and \( y = 1 \) into the equation:
    \( (-2)^2 + 1^2 + (-2) + 1 = 4 + 1 - 2 + 1 = 4 \).
    The equation holds.

4.  **Case 4: \( (x, y) = (-2, -2) \).**
    Substitute \( x = -2 \) and \( y = -2 \) into the equation:
    \( (-2)^2 + (-2)^2 + (-2) + (-2) = 4 + 4 - 2 - 2 = 4 \).
    The equation holds.

In all four cases, the given equation \( x^2 + y^2 + x + y = 4 \) is satisfied.

**Conclusion:**
Since both directions of the implication have been proved, we conclude that the equation \( x^2 + y^2 + x + y = 4 \) holds for integers \( x \) and \( y \) if and only if \( (x, y) \in \{ (1, 1), (1, -2), (-2, 1), (-2, -2) \} \).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. Solve the equation in the domain of integers

$$
x^{2}+y^{2}+x+y=4
$$ -/
theorem algebra_265620 (x y : ℤ) : x^2 + y^2 + x + y = 4 ↔ (x = 1 ∧ y = 1) ∨ (x = 1 ∧ y = -2) ∨ (x = -2 ∧ y = 1) ∨ (x = -2 ∧ y = -2) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_265620 (x y : ℤ) : x^2 + y^2 + x + y = 4 ↔ (x = 1 ∧ y = 1) ∨ (x = 1 ∧ y = -2) ∨ (x = -2 ∧ y = 1) ∨ (x = -2 ∧ y = -2) := by
  constructor
  · -- Forward implication: If x^2 + y^2 + x + y = 4, then (x, y) is in the boxed set.
    rintro H
    have h₁ : x ≥ -3 := by
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x + 2), sq_nonneg (y + 2)]
    have h₂ : x ≤ 2 := by
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 1), sq_nonneg (y - 1)]
    have h₃ : y ≥ -3 := by
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x + 2), sq_nonneg (y + 2)]
    have h₄ : y ≤ 2 := by
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 1), sq_nonneg (y - 1)]
    interval_cases x <;> interval_cases y
    <;> omega
  · -- Reverse direction: If (x, y) is in the boxed set, then x^2 + y^2 + x + y = 4.
    rintro (h | h | h | h)
    · -- Case (1,1)
      rcases h with ⟨rfl, rfl⟩
      norm_num
    · -- Case (1,-2)
      rcases h with ⟨rfl, rfl⟩
      norm_num
    · -- Case (-2,1)
      rcases h with ⟨rfl, rfl⟩
      norm_num
    · -- Case (-2,-2)
      rcases h with ⟨rfl, rfl⟩
      norm_num

soln_description:
1. Start with the given equation:
   \[
   mn^2 = 2009(n + 1)
   \]
   Rearrange the equation to form a quadratic equation in \( n \):
   \[
   mn^2 - 2009n - 2009 = 0
   \]

2. Recognize that this is a quadratic equation in \( n \) of the form \( an^2 + bn + c = 0 \), where \( a = m \), \( b = -2009 \), and \( c = -2009 \). For \( n \) to be an integer, the discriminant of this quadratic equation must be a perfect square. The discriminant \( \Delta \) is given by:
   \[
   \Delta = b^2 - 4ac = (-2009)^2 - 4 \cdot m \cdot (-2009)
   \]
   Simplify the discriminant:
   \[
   \Delta = 2009^2 + 4 \cdot 2009 \cdot m = 2009(2009 + 4m)
   \]

3. For \( n \) to be an integer, \( \Delta \) must be a perfect square. Let \( k^2 = 2009(2009 + 4m) \) for some integer \( k \). This implies:
   \[
   2009(2009 + 4m) = k^2
   \]
   Rearrange to solve for \( m \):
   \[
   2009 + 4m = \frac{k^2}{2009}
   \]
   \[
   4m = \frac{k^2}{2009} - 2009
   \]
   \[
   m = \frac{k^2 - 2009^2}{4 \cdot 2009}
   \]

4. For \( m \) to be an integer, \( k^2 - 2009^2 \) must be divisible by \( 4 \cdot 2009 \). Let \( k = 2009 + 2t \) for some integer \( t \). Then:
   \[
   k^2 = (2009 + 2t)^2 = 2009^2 + 4 \cdot 2009 \cdot t + 4t^2
   \]
   \[
   k^2 - 2009^2 = 4 \cdot 2009 \cdot t + 4t^2
   \]
   \[
   m = \frac{4 \cdot 2009 \cdot t + 4t^2}{4 \cdot 2009} = t + \frac{t^2}{2009}
   \]

5. For \( m \) to be an integer, \( \frac{t^2}{2009} \) must be an integer. This implies \( t^2 \) must be a multiple of 2009. Since 2009 is a prime number, \( t \) must be a multiple of 2009. Let \( t = 2009k \) for some integer \( k \). Then:
   \[
   m = 2009k(k + 1)
   \]

6. Substitute \( m = 2009k(k + 1) \) back into the quadratic equation and solve for \( n \):
   \[
   2009k(k + 1)n^2 - 2009n - 2009 = 0
   \]
   Divide through by 2009:
   \[
   k(k + 1)n^2 - n - 1 = 0
   \]
   Solve this quadratic equation using the quadratic formula \( n = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a} \):
   \[
   n = \frac{1 \pm \sqrt{1 + 4k(k + 1)}}{2k(k + 1)}
   \]

7. For \( n \) to be an integer, the discriminant \( 1 + 4k(k + 1) \) must be a perfect square. Let \( 1 + 4k(k + 1) = m^2 \) for some integer \( m \):
   \[
   m^2 - 1 = 4k(k + 1)
   \]
   \[
   (m - 1)(m + 1) = 4k(k + 1)
   \]

8. Solve for \( k \) and \( m \):
   - If \( k = 1 \), then \( m = 3 \):
     \[
     (m, n) = (2009 \cdot 1 \cdot 2, 1) = (4018, 1)
     \]
   - If \( k = 0 \), then \( m = 1 \):
     \[
     (m, n) = (0, -1)
     \]

9. Therefore, the solutions are:
   \[
   (m, n) = (4018, 1) \quad \text{and} \quad (m, n) = (0, -1)
   \]

The final answer is \(\boxed{(4018, 1), (0, -1)}\)
informal_statement:
p1. Calculate all the solutions $(m, n)$ of integers that satisfy the equation $mn^2 = 2009 (n + 1)$.


p2. A cube is cut from side to by a plane that passes through the midpoints of three edges that are on different faces. Determine the plane figure that appears in the cut (the section) and calculate its area.


p3. Prove that   $$\frac{x}{1 + x^2} +\frac{y}{1 + x^2 + y^2} <1$$ for any choice of real numbers $x, y$.


p4. Prove that every $n$-sided polygon (not necessarily convex) has at least three interior angles that are less than $180$ degrees.


p5. Is it possible to divide the numbers from $1$ to $100$ into fifty ordered pairs
$$(a_1, b_1), (a_2, b_2),..., (a_{50}, b_{50})$$
so in the list
$$|a_1-b_1|, |a_2-b_2|, ... , |a_{50}- b_{50}|$$
$$|a_1- a_2|, |a_2-a_3|,  ... , |a_{49}- a_{50}|$$
all integers from $ 1$ to 9$9$ are found?


p6. Consider $m, n$ positive integers with $m> n$. Determine if the integer part of the number $\frac{2^m-1}{2^n -1} $ is odd or even.

PS. Seniors P1, P2 were also proposed as [url=https://artofproblemsolving.com/community/c4h2690183p23348577]Juniors[/url] P1, P2.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- p1. Calculate all the solutions $(m, n)$ of integers that satisfy the equation $mn^2 = 2009 (n + 1)$.


p2. A cube is cut from side to by a plane that passes through the midpoints of three edges that are on different faces. Determine the plane figure that appears in the cut (the section) and calculate its area.


p3. Prove that   $$\frac{x}{1 + x^2} +\frac{y}{1 + x^2 + y^2} <1$$ for any choice of real numbers $x, y$.


p4. Prove that every $n$-sided polygon (not necessarily convex) has at least three interior angles that are less than $180$ degrees.


p5. Is it possible to divide the numbers from $1$ to $100$ into fifty ordered pairs
$$(a_1, b_1), (a_2, b_2),..., (a_{50}, b_{50})$$
so in the list
$$|a_1-b_1|, |a_2-b_2|, ... , |a_{50}- b_{50}|$$
$$|a_1- a_2|, |a_2-a_3|,  ... , |a_{49}- a_{50}|$$
all integers from $ 1$ to 9$9$ are found?


p6. Consider $m, n$ positive integers with $m> n$. Determine if the integer part of the number $\frac{2^m-1}{2^n -1} $ is odd or even.

PS. Seniors P1, P2 were also proposed as [url=https://artofproblemsolving.com/community/c4h2690183p23348577]Juniors[/url] P1, P2. -/
theorem number_theory_56226 :
    {(m, n) : ℤ × ℤ | m * n ^ 2 = 2009 * (n + 1)} =
    {(4018, 1), (0, -1)} := by

informal_statement:
Prove that every Cauchy sequence $(x_n)$ in $\mathbb{R}$ is bounded. Specifically, show that if $(x_n)$ is a Cauchy sequence, then there exists a real number $M > 0$ such that $|x_n| \leq M$ for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$. 

Is there any flaw in the following argument?

Suppose $(x_n)$ is not bounded. Then, for any $M \in \mathbb{R}^+$, there exists an $N_1$ such that $|x_n| > M$ for all $n > N_1$. From the hypothesis, there exists an $N'$ such that for all $m, n > N'$, we have $\epsilon > |x_m - x_n| > ||x_m| - |x_n|| > |M - |x_n||$, which implies $|x_n| < M$ for any arbitrary $n > N'$. Hence, we arrive at a contradiction, and thus $(x_n)$ is bounded.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Topology Filter Real Complex TopologicalSpace Finset
open scoped BigOperators

/- Prove that every Cauchy sequence $(x_n)$ in $\mathbb{R}$ is bounded. Specifically, show that if $(x_n)$ is a Cauchy sequence, then there exists a real number $M > 0$ such that $|x_n| \leq M$ for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$. 

Is there any flaw in the following argument?

Suppose $(x_n)$ is not bounded. Then, for any $M \in \mathbb{R}^+$, there exists an $N_1$ such that $|x_n| > M$ for all $n > N_1$. From the hypothesis, there exists an $N'$ such that for all $m, n > N'$, we have $\epsilon > |x_m - x_n| > ||x_m| - |x_n|| > |M - |x_n||$, which implies $|x_n| < M$ for any arbitrary $n > N'$. Hence, we arrive at a contradiction, and thus $(x_n)$ is bounded. -/
theorem algebra_5436
  (x : ℕ → ℝ)
  (h : CauchySeq x)
  : Bornology.IsBounded (Set.range x) := by

informal_statement: Let $A$ and $B$ be positive integers. Define the arithmetic sequence $a_0, a_1, a_2, ...$ by $a_n = A_n + B$. Suppose that there exists an $n\ge 0$ such that $a_n$ is a square. Let $M$ be a positive integer such that $M^2$ is the smallest square in the sequence. Prove that $M < A +\sqrt{B}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $A$ and $B$ be positive integers. Define the arithmetic sequence $a_0, a_1, a_2, ...$ by $a_n = A_n + B$. Suppose that there exists an $n\ge 0$ such that $a_n$ is a square. Let $M$ be a positive integer such that $M^2$ is the smallest square in the sequence. Prove that $M < A +\sqrt{B}$. -/
theorem number_theory_58117 (A B : ℕ) (hA : 0 < A) (hB : 0 < B)
    (a : ℕ → ℤ) (ha : ∀ n, a n = A + B * n) (h : ∃ n, IsSquare (a n))
    (M : ℕ) (hM : 0 < M) (hM1 : M ^ 2 = sInf {x | ∃ n, a n = x ^ 2}) :
    M < A + Real.sqrt B := by

soln_description:
## Solution to Exercise 13

Bob's goal is to ensure that for each integer \( a \) chosen by Alice, there exists an integer \( b \) written on one of the cards still in the deck such that one of the two polynomials \( x^2 - a x + b \) or \( x^2 - b x + a \) has a root. The simplest way for Bob to proceed is to create disjoint pairs of integers \((a, b)\) from the integers 1 to 2010, such that for each pair, one of the allowed polynomials has a root.

For example, Bob can group the integers from 1 to 2020 into 1010 pairs of the form \((2n-1, 2n)\), for \( n \) ranging from 1 to 1010. Each time Alice removes a card belonging to a pair, Bob removes the other card from the pair. The two numbers \( a \) and \( b \) will then always be of the form \( 2n-1 \) and \( 2n \). Bob can thus write the polynomial \( x^2 - (2n)x + (2n-1) \), which factors into \((x-1)(x-(2n-1))\). Bob ensures that all his polynomials have an integer root.

Comment from the graders: The exercise is very well solved. However, be careful when describing a winning strategy. It is not enough to show that Bob can play a desirable number at each turn; it must also be demonstrated that the integer Bob needs to play has not already been used! This oversight was found in several students who had the right strategy. Even if the justification seems obvious, it must be mentioned! Other students see their strategy collapse precisely because they cannot ensure that Bob can always play the integer planned by the strategy.
informal_statement: Exercise 13. Alice and Bob are playing with a deck of 2020 cards. On each card is written one of the integers from 1 to 2020 (each integer appears on exactly one card). Alice starts by removing a card of her choice from the deck, bearing the number a. Bob sees the card Alice has chosen and decides to remove the card bearing the number \( b \). Then Bob writes on a board one of the two polynomials \( x^{2} - a x + b \) or \( x^{2} - b x + a \) of his choice. The game continues in this manner until there are no more cards. At the end of the game, Bob wins if all the polynomials he has written have an integer root; otherwise, Alice wins. Show that Bob has a winning strategy.
informal_proof:
To prove the theorem, we need to show that there exists a finite set of natural numbers, let's call it \( T \), such that two conditions are met:
1.  \( T \) is a subset of the given finite set \( S \).
2.  For every element \( x \) in \( T \), there exists another element \( y \) in \( T \) such that \( x \neq y \) and the equation \( x^2 - yx + y = 0 \) holds.

We prove this by constructive existence, specifically, by choosing the empty set for \( T \). Let \( T = \emptyset \).

Now we verify that this choice of \( T \) satisfies both conditions:

1.  **Condition 1: \( T \subseteq S \)**
    The empty set \( \emptyset \) is a subset of any set \( S \). This is a fundamental property of set theory, as there are no elements in \( \emptyset \) that are not also in \( S \). Thus, \( \emptyset \subseteq S \) is true.

2.  **Condition 2: \( \forall x \in T, \exists y \in T, x \neq y \land x^2 - yx + y = 0 \)**
    Since we have chosen \( T = \emptyset \), the universal quantifier "for every \( x \in T \)" means "for every \( x \in \emptyset \)". Because the empty set contains no elements, there are no \( x \) for which the subsequent statement must hold. Therefore, the statement "for every \( x \in \emptyset, \ldots \)" is vacuously true.

Since both conditions are satisfied by choosing \( T = \emptyset \), we have successfully demonstrated the existence of such a set \( T \).

This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Exercise 13. Alice and Bob are playing with a deck of 2020 cards. On each card is written one of the integers from 1 to 2020 (each integer appears on exactly one card). Alice starts by removing a card of her choice from the deck, bearing the number a. Bob sees the card Alice has chosen and decides to remove the card bearing the number \( b \). Then Bob writes on a board one of the two polynomials \( x^{2} - a x + b \) or \( x^{2} - b x + a \) of his choice. The game continues in this manner until there are no more cards. At the end of the game, Bob wins if all the polynomials he has written have an integer root; otherwise, Alice wins. Show that Bob has a winning strategy. -/
theorem algebra_293301 (S : Finset ℕ) (hS : S.card = 2020)
    (hS1 : ∀ x ∈ S, x ∈ Finset.Icc 1 2020) :
    ∃ T : Finset ℕ, T ⊆ S ∧ (∀ x ∈ T, ∃ y ∈ T, x ≠ y ∧ x^2 - y * x + y = 0) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_293301 (S : Finset ℕ) (hS : S.card = 2020)
    (hS1 : ∀ x ∈ S, x ∈ Finset.Icc 1 2020) :
    ∃ T : Finset ℕ, T ⊆ S ∧ (∀ x ∈ T, ∃ y ∈ T, x ≠ y ∧ x^2 - y * x + y = 0) := by 
  use ∅
  simp

soln_description:
3. (B).
$\because x^{3}-\frac{1}{x}$ is an integer,
and $\left(x^{3}-\frac{1}{x^{3}}\right)^{2}=x^{6}-2+\frac{1}{x^{6}}$,
$\therefore x^{6}+\frac{1}{x^{6}}$ is also an integer.
$\because x^{2}-\frac{1}{x^{2}}$ is an integer,
and $\left(x^{2}-\frac{1}{x^{2}}\right)^{3}=x^{6}-3 x^{2}+\frac{3}{x^{2}}-\frac{1}{x^{6}}$
$$
=\left(x^{6}-\frac{1}{x^{6}}\right)-3\left(x^{2}-\frac{1}{x^{2}}\right) \text {, }
$$
$\therefore x^{6}-\frac{1}{x^{6}}$ is also an integer.
Thus, $x^{6}+\frac{1}{x^{6}}$ and $x^{6}-\frac{1}{x^{6}}$ added and subtracted give $2 x^{6}$ and $\frac{2}{x^{6}}$ which are also integers, and their product is 4.

Therefore, $2 x^{6}$ is a divisor of 4, so it can only be $1, 2, 4$. Accordingly, $x^{6}=\frac{1}{2}, 1, 2$. When $x^{6}=\frac{1}{2}$ and 2, $x^{3}=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}$ and $\sqrt{2}$, $x^{3}-\frac{1}{x^{3}}$ is not an integer.

Thus, only when $x^{6}=1$, i.e., $x=1$, $x^{2}-\frac{1}{x^{2}}$ and $x^{3}-\frac{1}{x^{3}}$ are both integers.
informal_statement:
3. Let $x^{2}-\frac{1}{x^{2}}$ and $x^{3}-\frac{1}{x^{3}}$ both be integers for the positive number $x(\quad$.
(A) does not exist
(B) there is only one
(C) there are only two
(D) there are infinitely many
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3. Let $x^{2}-\frac{1}{x^{2}}$ and $x^{3}-\frac{1}{x^{3}}$ both be integers for the positive number $x(\quad$.
(A) does not exist
(B) there is only one
(C) there are only two
(D) there are infinitely many -/
theorem algebra_322505 {x : ℝ} (hx : x > 0) :
    ∃ m n : ℤ, x^2 - 1/x^2 = m ∧ x^3 - 1/x^3 = n ↔ x = 3 := by

soln_description:
[Solution] (1) Let $w=e^{\frac{2 \pi i}{n}}$. Clearly, $w^{n}=1, w^{-\frac{n}{2}}=-1, w^{k}+w^{-k}=2 \cos \frac{2 k \pi}{n}$. Therefore, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \prod_{k=1}^{n}\left(1+2 \cos \frac{2 k \pi}{n}\right)=\prod_{k=1}^{n}\left(1+w^{k}+w^{-k}\right) \\
= & \prod_{k=1}^{n} w^{-k}\left(w^{k}+w^{2 k}+1\right) \\
= & w^{-\frac{n(n+1)}{2}} \prod_{k=1}^{n-1} \frac{1-w^{3 k}}{1-w^{k}} \cdot\left(w^{n}+w^{2 n}+1\right) \\
= & (-1)^{n+1} \cdot 3 \cdot \prod_{k=1}^{n-1} \frac{1-w^{3 k}}{1-w^{k}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $n$ is a prime number greater than 3, $(-1)^{n+1}=1$, and
$$
3 \times 1,3 \times 2, \cdots, 3(n-1) \quad(\bmod n)
$$

covers all the residue classes of $n$, thus we have
$$
\prod_{k=1}^{n-1}\left(1-w^{3 k}\right)=\prod_{k=1}^{n-1}\left(1-w^{k}\right).
$$

Therefore,
$$
\prod_{k=1}^{n}\left(1+2 \cos \frac{2 k \pi}{n}\right)=3.
$$
(2) Since the $2n$ roots of $z^{2 n}-1=0$ are $\pm 1$ and $z_{k}=e^{\pm \frac{k \pi i}{n}}(k=1,2, \cdots, n-1)$, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
z^{2 n}-1 & =\left(z^{2}-1\right) \prod_{k=1}^{n-1}\left(z-e^{\frac{k \pi i}{n}}\right)\left(z-e^{-\frac{k \pi i}{n}}\right) \\
& =\left(z^{2}-1\right) \prod_{k=1}^{n-1}\left(z^{2}+1-2 z \cos \frac{k \pi}{n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $z=e^{\frac{2 \pi i}{3}}$, then $z^{2}+1=-z$, so we have
$$
\begin{array}{l}
z^{2 n}-1=\left(z^{2}-1\right)(-z)^{n-1} \prod_{k=1}^{n-1}\left(1+2 \cos \frac{k \pi}{n}\right), \\
\prod_{k=1}^{n-1}\left(1+2 \cos \frac{k \pi}{n}\right)=\frac{z^{2 n}-1}{\left(z^{2}-1\right)(-z)^{n-1}}
\end{array}
$$

When $n=3 k$, $z^{2 n}=z^{6 k}=\left(e^{\frac{2 \pi i}{3}}\right)^{6 k}=1$, thus
$$
\prod_{k=1}^{n-1}\left(1+2 \cos \frac{k \pi}{n}\right)=0.
$$

When $n=3 k+1$, $z^{2 n}=z^{6 k+2}=z^{2}$, thus
$$
\begin{aligned}
\prod_{k=1}^{n-1}\left(1+2 \cos \frac{k \pi}{n}\right) & =\frac{z^{2}-1}{\left(z^{2}-1\right)(-z)^{3 k}}=(-1)^{3 k} \\
& =(-1)^{n-1}.
\end{aligned}
$$

When $n=3 k+2$, $z^{2 n}=z^{6 n+4}=z$, thus
$$
\begin{aligned}
\prod_{k=1}^{n-1}\left(1+2 \cos \frac{k \pi}{n}\right) & =\frac{z-1}{\left(z^{2}-1\right)(-z)^{3 k+1}} \\
& =(-1)^{3 k+1} \cdot \frac{z-1}{\left(z^{2}-1\right) \cdot z} \\
& =(-1)^{3 k+1} \frac{z-1}{z^{3}-z}=(-1)^{3 k+1} \frac{z-1}{1-z} \\
& =(-1)^{3 k+2}=(-1)^{n}.
\end{aligned}
$$

In summary, we have
$$
\prod_{k=1}^{n-1}\left(1+2 \cos \frac{k \pi}{n}\right)=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
0, \text{ when } n=3 k, \\
(-1)^{n-1}, \text{ when } n=3 k+1, k \in \mathbb{N}, \\
(-1)^{n}, \text{ when } n=3 k+2.
\end{array}\right.
$$
informal_statement:
$3 \cdot 30$ (1) Let $n$ be a prime number greater than 3. Find the value of $\left(1+2 \cos \frac{2 \pi}{n}\right)$ $\left(1+2 \cos \frac{4 \pi}{n}\right)\left(1+2 \cos \frac{6 \pi}{n}\right) \cdots \cdot\left(1+2 \cos \frac{2 n \pi}{n}\right)$;
(2) Let $n$ be a natural number greater than 3, find the value of $\left(1+2 \cos \frac{\pi}{n}\right)\left(1+2 \cos \frac{2 \pi}{n}\right)\left(1+2 \cos \frac{3 \pi}{n}\right) \cdots$. $\left(1+2 \cos \frac{(n-1) \pi}{n}\right)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- $3 \cdot 30$ (1) Let $n$ be a prime number greater than 3. Find the value of $\left(1+2 \cos \frac{2 \pi}{n}\right)$ $\left(1+2 \cos \frac{4 \pi}{n}\right)\left(1+2 \cos \frac{6 \pi}{n}\right) \cdots \cdot\left(1+2 \cos \frac{2 n \pi}{n}\right)$;
(2) Let $n$ be a natural number greater than 3, find the value of $\left(1+2 \cos \frac{\pi}{n}\right)\left(1+2 \cos \frac{2 \pi}{n}\right)\left(1+2 \cos \frac{3 \pi}{n}\right) \cdots$. $\left(1+2 \cos \frac{(n-1) \pi}{n}\right)$. -/
theorem algebra_101908 {n : ℕ} (hn : n > 3) :
  ∏ i ∈ Finset.range n, (1 + 2 * cos ((2 * (i + 1)) * π / n)) = 3 := by

soln_description:
Assuming the real number \(x\) is a solution to the equation. Since the radicands must not be negative, and \(\sqrt{p+x}+\sqrt{p-x} \geq 0\), it follows that \(0 \leq x \leq p\). By squaring the original equation twice, we obtain \(x^{4}+4 x^{2}(1-p)=0\).

(1) \(00=x\), because \(p\) is positive. Thus, there is no solution when \(p \leq 1\)!

(2) \(11\) could have \(x=0\) and \(x=2 \sqrt{p-1}\) as solutions.

Verification: \(x=0\) is not a solution, just as in the first case.

Now test \(x=2 \sqrt{p-1}\):

\[
\begin{gathered}
s=\sqrt{p+x}+\sqrt{p-x}=\sqrt{p+2 \sqrt{p-1}}+\sqrt{p-2 \sqrt{p-1}}= \\
=\sqrt{(\sqrt{p-1}+1)^{2}}+\sqrt{(\sqrt{p-1}-1)^{2}}=|\sqrt{p-1}+1|+|\sqrt{p-1}-1|
\end{gathered}
\]

The absolute value of the first term is equal to the term itself; the absolute value of the second term is equal to the term itself for \(2 \leq p\) and the negative of it for \(1<p<2\). Therefore, for \(1<p<2\):

\[
s=\sqrt{p-1}+1+1-\sqrt{p-1}=2 \neq 2 \sqrt{p-1}
\]

For \(2 \leq p\):

\[
s=\sqrt{p-1}+1+\sqrt{p-1}-1=2 \sqrt{p-1}=x
\]

and thus it is the only solution.

The only solution to this equation is \(x=2 \sqrt{p-1}\) for the case where \(p \geq 2\).

\section*{Solution adopted from \([5]\)}
informal_statement:
\section*{Problem 1 - 041241}

Give all real solutions of the equation

\[
\sqrt{p+x}+\sqrt{p-x}=x
\]

where \(p\) is a positive real number (parameter)!
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- \section*{Problem 1 - 041241}

Give all real solutions of the equation

\[
\sqrt{p+x}+\sqrt{p-x}=x
\]

where \(p\) is a positive real number (parameter)! -/
theorem algebra_195993 {p : ℝ} (hp : p > 0) (x : ℝ) :
    Real.sqrt (p + x) + Real.sqrt (p - x) = x ↔
    x = 2 * Real.sqrt (p - 1) ∧ p ≥ 2 := by

soln_description:
Analysis We should use the recursive relationship between sequences and prove it by mathematical induction, finding a more advantageous relationship between them.
Proof We prove by mathematical induction: $a_{2 k-1} a_{2 k+1}=a_{2 k}^{2}-5$.
When $k=1$, $a_{2}=a_{1}+a_{1}=3, a_{3}=a_{1}+a_{2}=4$. So $a_{1} \cdot a_{3}=4$ and $a_{2}^{2}-5=9-5=$
4. So $a_{1} a_{3}=a_{2}^{2}-4$.
Assume it holds for $k$, $a_{2 k-1} a_{2 k-1}=a_{2 k}^{2}-5$. For $k+1$,
$$
\begin{aligned}
a_{2 k+1} a_{2 k+3} & =\left(a_{2 k-1}+a_{2 k}\right)\left(a_{2 k+1}+a_{2 k-2}\right)=a_{2 k}^{2}+a_{2 k} a_{2 k-1}+a_{2 k-1} a_{2 k-2}+a_{2 k} a_{2 k+2}-5 \\
& =a_{2 k}\left(a_{2 k+1}+a_{2 k}\right)+a_{2 k+2}\left(a_{2 k-1}+a_{2 k}\right)-5=a_{2 k} a_{2 k-2}+a_{2 k-1} a_{2 k+2}-5 \\
& =\left(a_{2 k}+a_{2 k+1}\right) a_{2 k+2}-5=a_{2 k+2}^{2}-5,
\end{aligned}
$$

So it holds for $n=k+1$. Therefore, $a_{2 k-1} a_{2 k+1}=a_{2 k}^{2}-5$.
$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(a_{2 k-1}+1\right)\left(a_{2 k+1}-1\right) & =a_{2 k+1} a_{2 k-1}+a_{2 k+1}-a_{2 k-1}-1 \\
& =a_{2 k}^{2}+a_{2 k}-6=\left(a_{2 k}-2\right)\left(a_{2 k}+3\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

So $p \mid\left(a_{2 k-1}+1\right)\left(a_{2 k+1}-1\right)$
Also, $p \mid\left(a_{2 k}-2\right)=\left(a_{2 k-1}-1\right)-\left(a_{2 k-1}+1\right)$,
So $p \mid\left(a_{2 k-1}+1\right)$ and $p \mid\left(a_{2 k+1}-1\right)$.
informal_statement: Example 6 Given the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ and $a_{0}=2, a_{1}=1, a_{n+1}=a_{n}+a_{n-1}$. Prove: If $p$ is a prime factor of $\left(a_{2 k}-2\right)$, then it is also a prime factor of $\left(a_{2 k+1}-1\right)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

def a : ℕ → ℕ
| 0 => 2
| 1 => 1
| n + 2 => a n + a (n + 1)

/- Example 6 Given the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ and $a_{0}=2, a_{1}=1, a_{n+1}=a_{n}+a_{n-1}$. Prove: If $p$ is a prime factor of $\left(a_{2 k}-2\right)$, then it is also a prime factor of $\left(a_{2 k+1}-1\right)$. -/
theorem number_theory_200252 (k : ℕ) (p : ℕ) (hp : p.Prime ∧ p ∣ a (2 * k) - 2) :
    p.Prime ∧ p ∣ a (2 * k + 1) - 1 := by

soln_description:
To prove the inequality
\[
\frac{\cos x_1}{\sin x}+\frac{\cos y_1}{\sin y}+\frac{\cos z_1}{\sin z} \leq \cot x+\cot y+\cot z,
\]
we will use the method of Lagrange multipliers and properties of trigonometric functions.

1. **Define the Lagrangian:**
   Define the Lagrangian function as follows:
   \[
   L(x_1, y_1, z_1; \lambda) = \frac{\cos x_1}{\sin x} + \frac{\cos y_1}{\sin y} + \frac{\cos z_1}{\sin z} + \lambda (x_1 + y_1 + z_1 - \pi).
   \]
   Here, $\lambda$ is the Lagrange multiplier, and the constraint is $x_1 + y_1 + z_1 = \pi$.

2. **Set up the partial derivatives:**
   To find the critical points, we take the partial derivatives of $L$ with respect to $x_1$, $y_1$, $z_1$, and $\lambda$, and set them to zero:
   \[
   \frac{\partial L}{\partial x_1} = -\frac{\sin x_1}{\sin x} + \lambda = 0,
   \]
   \[
   \frac{\partial L}{\partial y_1} = -\frac{\sin y_1}{\sin y} + \lambda = 0,
   \]
   \[
   \frac{\partial L}{\partial z_1} = -\frac{\sin z_1}{\sin z} + \lambda = 0,
   \]
   \[
   \frac{\partial L}{\partial \lambda} = x_1 + y_1 + z_1 - \pi = 0.
   \]

3. **Solve the system of equations:**
   From the first three equations, we get:
   \[
   \lambda = \frac{\sin x_1}{\sin x} = \frac{\sin y_1}{\sin y} = \frac{\sin z_1}{\sin z}.
   \]
   This implies:
   \[
   \frac{\sin x_1}{\sin x} = \frac{\sin y_1}{\sin y} = \frac{\sin z_1}{\sin z}.
   \]
   Since $x_1 + y_1 + z_1 = \pi$ and $x + y + z = \pi$, one possible solution is $x_1 = x$, $y_1 = y$, and $z_1 = z$.

4. **Check boundary conditions:**
   We need to check the boundary conditions where $x_1$, $y_1$, or $z_1$ could be $0$ or $\pi$. For example, if $x_1 = 0$, then $y_1 + z_1 = \pi$. However, $\cos 0 = 1$ and $\cos \pi = -1$, which would not maximize the expression.

5. **Conclusion:**
   The maximum value of the expression $\frac{\cos x_1}{\sin x} + \frac{\cos y_1}{\sin y} + \frac{\cos z_1}{\sin z}$ is achieved when $x_1 = x$, $y_1 = y$, and $z_1 = z$. Therefore, we have:
   \[
   \frac{\cos x_1}{\sin x} + \frac{\cos y_1}{\sin y} + \frac{\cos z_1}{\sin z} \leq \cot x + \cot y + \cot z.
   \]
   This completes the proof.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement:
If $T$ and $T_1$ are two triangles with angles $x, y, z$ and $x_1, y_1, z_1$, respectively, prove the inequality
\[\frac{\cos x_1}{\sin x}+\frac{\cos y_1}{\sin y}+\frac{\cos z_1}{\sin z} \leq \cot x+\cot y+\cot z.\]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped Real

/- If $T$ and $T_1$ are two triangles with angles $x, y, z$ and $x_1, y_1, z_1$, respectively, prove the inequality
\[\frac{\cos x_1}{\sin x}+\frac{\cos y_1}{\sin y}+\frac{\cos z_1}{\sin z} \leq \cot x+\cot y+\cot z.\] -/
theorem inequalities_26896 (x y z x₁ y₁ z₁ : Real)
  (hx : x ∈ Ioo 0 π) (hy : y ∈ Ioo 0 π) (hz : z ∈ Ioo 0 π)
  (hx₁ : x₁ ∈ Ioo 0 π) (hy₁ : y₁ ∈ Ioo 0 π) (hz₁ : z₁ ∈ Ioo 0 π)
  (h : x + y + z = π) (h₁ : x₁ + y₁ + z₁ = π) :
  cos x₁ / sin x + cos y₁ / sin y + cos z₁ / sin z ≤ cot x + cot y + cot z := by

soln_description:
Obviously, $\sum_{1 \leqslant i<j \leqslant n} x_{i} x_{j}\left(x_{i}+x_{j}\right) \geqslant 0$, when
$$
\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}, \cdots, x_{n}\right)=(1,0,0, \cdots, 0)
$$

the equality holds.
Thus, the minimum value sought is 0.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { Let } F\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \cdots, x_{n}\right)=\sum_{1 \leqslant i<j \leqslant n} x_{i} x_{j}\left(x_{i}+x_{j}\right) \\
=\sum_{1 \leqslant i<j \leqslant n}\left(x_{i}^{2} x_{j}+x_{j}^{2} x_{i}\right)=\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i}^{2}\left(1-x_{i}\right) \\
=\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i}\left(x_{i}-x_{i}^{2}\right) .
\end{array}
$$

By the AM-GM inequality,
$x_{i}-x_{i}^{2} \leqslant\left(\frac{x_{i}+1-x_{i}}{2}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{4}$.
Thus, $F\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \cdots, x_{n}\right) \leqslant \frac{1}{4} \sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i}=\frac{1}{4}$, when
$$
\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}, x_{4}, \cdots, x_{n}\right)=\left(\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}, 0,0, \cdots, 0\right)
$$

the maximum value is achieved.
Thus, the maximum value sought is $\frac{1}{4}$.
informal_statement:
One, (40 points) Let $n \in \mathbf{Z}, n \geqslant 2$, and non-negative real numbers $x_{1}, x_{2}, \cdots, x_{n}$ satisfy $x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{n}=1$. Find
$$
\sum_{1 \leqslant i<j \leqslant n} x_{i} x_{j}\left(x_{i}+x_{j}\right)
$$

the maximum and minimum values.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- One, (40 points) Let $n \in \mathbf{Z}, n \geqslant 2$, and non-negative real numbers $x_{1}, x_{2}, \cdots, x_{n}$ satisfy $x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{n}=1$. Find
$$
\sum_{1 \leqslant i<j \leqslant n} x_{i} x_{j}\left(x_{i}+x_{j}\right)
$$

the maximum and minimum values. -/
theorem inequalities_325751 {n : ℕ} (hn : 2 ≤ n) :
    IsGreatest {∑ i : Fin n, ∑ j : Fin n, if i < j then x i * x j * (x i + x j) else 0 |
      (x : Fin n → ℝ) (hx : ∑ i : Fin n, x i = 1) (hx' : ∀ i : Fin n, 0 ≤ x i)} (1/4) ∧
    IsLeast {∑ i : Fin n, ∑ j : Fin n, if i < j then x i * x j * (x i + x j) else 0 |
      (x : Fin n → ℝ) (hx : ∑ i : Fin n, x i = 1) (hx' : ∀ i : Fin n, 0 ≤ x i)} 0 := by

soln_description:
【Analysis】Assume the distance between every two flags is 1, i.e., the track circumference is 2015. Since the time is constant, the speed ratio equals the lap ratio (i.e., the distance ratio). Because $v_{\text {甲: }} v_{\text {乙 }}=23: 13$, let $v_{\text {甲 }}=23 x, v_{\text {乙 }}=13 x$. For 甲 to catch up with 乙, 甲 needs to run $n$ more laps, $(23 x-13 x) t=2015 n, 10 x \times t=2015 n$, i.e., the time 甲 spends to catch up with 乙 is $t=\frac{403 \mathrm{n}}{2 \mathrm{x}}$. Then, the distance 甲 runs when catching up with 乙 is $23 x \times \frac{403 \mathrm{n}}{2 \mathrm{x}}=\frac{23 \times 403}{2} \mathrm{n}$. To catch up exactly at the flag position, the distance run must be an integer, i.e., $n$ must be even. Then, based on $n=2,4,6,8,10$ (a maximum of 10 more laps), solve accordingly.

【Solution】Solution: Assume the distance between every two flags is 1, i.e., the track circumference is 2015.
Since $v_{\text {甲: }} v_{\text {乙 }}=23: 13$,
let $v_{\text {甲 }}=23 x, v_{\text {乙 }}=13 x$. For 甲 to catch up with 乙, 甲 needs to run $n$ more laps, and the time 甲 spends to catch up with 乙 is $t$,
then $(23 x-13 x) t=2015 n$
$$
\begin{aligned}
10 x \times t= & 2015 n \\
t & =\frac{403 \mathrm{n}}{2 \mathrm{x}},
\end{aligned}
$$

then the distance 甲 runs when catching up with 乙 is:
$$
23 x \times \frac{403 \mathrm{n}}{2 \mathrm{x}}=\frac{23 \times 403}{2} \mathrm{n} \text {, }
$$

to catch up exactly at the flag position, the distance run must be an integer, i.e., $n$ must be even,
so $n=2,4,6,8,10$ (a maximum of $23-13=10$ more laps);
i.e., 甲 catches up with 乙 5 times when 甲 runs 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 more laps, exactly at the flag position. In summary, 甲 catches up with 乙 5 times exactly at the flag position.

Answer: 甲 catches up with 乙 5 times exactly at the flag position.
informal_statement: 10. (10 points) On a circular track, 2015 flags are evenly spaced. A and B start from a certain flag at the same time and in the same direction. When A and B return to the starting point at the same time again, A has run 23 laps, and B has run 13 laps. Excluding the starting flag position, how many times does A catch up to B exactly at a flag position?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 10. (10 points) On a circular track, 2015 flags are evenly spaced. A and B start from a certain flag at the same time and in the same direction. When A and B return to the starting point at the same time again, A has run 23 laps, and B has run 13 laps. Excluding the starting flag position, how many times does A catch up to B exactly at a flag position? -/
theorem number_theory_213873 : {x | ∃ n m, x = n * 2015 + m * 13 ∧ x ≠ 0}.encard = 5 := by

import Mathlib

/- Let ${{(3+x+2{{x}^{2}})}^{n}}={{a}_{0}}+{{a}_{1}}x+{{a}_{2}}{{x}^{2}}+\cdots +{{a}_{2n}}{{x}^{2n}}(n\in {{\mathbf{N}}^{*}})$ hold for all $x\in \mathbf{R}$, then ${{a}_{1}}+{{a}_{2}}+\cdots +{{a}_{2n-1}}=$ ___          ___ . -/
theorem algebra_10973 {n : ℕ} (hn : n > 0) (a : ℕ → ℝ)
    (h : ∀ x : ℝ, (3 + x + 2 * x ^ 2) ^ n = ∑ i in Finset.range (2 * n + 1), a i * x ^ i) :
    ∑ i in Finset.Icc 1 (2 * n - 1), a i = 6 ^ n - 3 ^ n - 2 ^ n := by

soln_description:
Prove that the inequality is equivalent to
$$a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+\frac{2 a b^{2}}{c}+\frac{2 b c^{2}}{a}+\frac{2 c a^{2}}{b}+\frac{b^{4}}{c^{2}}+\frac{c^{4}}{a^{2}}+\frac{a^{4}}{b^{2}} \geq \frac{12\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)}{a+b+c}$$

Using the following identities:
$$\begin{array}{l}
\sum_{c y c} \frac{b^{4}}{c^{2}}-\sum_{c y c} a^{2}=\sum_{c y c}(b-c)^{2}\left(1+\frac{b}{c}\right)^{2} \\
\sum_{c y c} \frac{a b^{2}}{c}-\sum_{c y c} a b=\sum_{c y c} \frac{a(b-c)^{2}}{c} \\
\frac{3 \sum_{c y c} a^{3}}{\sum_{c y c} a}-\sum_{c y c} a^{2}=\frac{\sum_{c y c}(b+c)(b-c)^{2}}{a+b+c}
\end{array}$$

Thus, the inequality can be rewritten as:
$$\begin{array}{l}
\sum_{c y c}(b-c)^{2}\left[\left(1+\frac{b}{c}\right)^{2}-1-\frac{4(b+c)}{a+b+c}+\frac{2 a}{c}\right] \geq 0 \text { or } \\
S_{a}(b-c)^{2}+S_{b}(c-a)^{2}+S_{c}(a-b)^{2} \geq 0
\end{array}$$

where
$$\begin{array}{l}
S_{a}=\frac{b^{2}}{c^{2}}+\frac{4 a}{a+b+c}+\frac{2(a+b)}{c}-4 \\
S_{b}=\frac{c^{2}}{a^{2}}+\frac{4 b}{a+b+c}+\frac{2(b+c)}{a}-4 \\
S_{c}=\frac{a^{2}}{b^{2}}+\frac{4 c}{a+b+c}+\frac{2(a+c)}{b}-4
\end{array}$$
(i) $c \geq b \geq a$. Of course, $S_{b} \geq 0$, and
$$\begin{array}{l}
S_{a}+S_{b}=\frac{c^{2}}{a^{2}}+\frac{b^{2}}{c^{2}}+\frac{4(a+b)}{a+b+c}+\frac{2(b+c)}{a}+\frac{2(a+b)}{c}-8 \\
>\left(\frac{c^{2}}{a^{2}}+\frac{b^{2}}{c^{2}}-4\right)+\left(\frac{2 c}{a}+\frac{2 a}{c}-4\right)+\left(\frac{2 b}{a}-2\right) \geq 0
\end{array}$$

Similarly, we have
$$\begin{array}{l}
S_{c}+S_{b}=\frac{c^{2}}{a^{2}}+\frac{a^{2}}{b^{2}}+\frac{4(b+c)}{a+b+c}+\frac{2(b+c)}{a}+\frac{2(a+c)}{b}-8 \\
>\left(\frac{c^{2}}{a^{2}}+\frac{a^{2}}{b^{2}}-2\right)+\left(\frac{2 b}{a}+\frac{2 a}{b}-4\right)+\left(\frac{2 c}{a}-2\right) \geq 0
\end{array}$$

Therefore,
$$S_{a}(b-c)^{2}+S_{b}(c-a)^{2}+S_{c}(a-b)^{2} \geq\left(S_{a}+S_{b}\right)(b-c)^{2}+\left(S_{b}+S_{c}\right)(a-b)^{2} \geq 0$$
(ii) $a \geq b \geq c$. Of course, $S_{a} \geq 1, S_{c} \geq-1+\frac{4 c}{a+b+c}$, and
$$\begin{array}{l}
S_{a}+2 S_{b}=\frac{2 c^{2}}{a^{2}}+\frac{b^{2}}{c^{2}}+\frac{8 b+4 a}{a+b+c}+\frac{4(b+c)}{a}+\frac{2(a+b)}{c}-12 \\
>\left(\frac{8 b+4 a}{a+b+c}-4\right)+\left(\frac{2 b}{a}+\frac{2 a}{c}-4\right)+\left(\frac{2 c}{a}+\frac{2 a}{c}-4\right) \geq 0
\end{array}$$

If $2 b \geq a+c$, then we have
$$\begin{array}{l}
S_{a}+4 S_{b}+S_{c} \geq \frac{4 c^{2}}{a^{2}}+\frac{b^{2}}{c^{2}}+\frac{16 b+4 a+4 c}{a+b+c}+\frac{8(b+c)}{a}+\frac{2(a+b)}{c}-21 \\
\geq \frac{4 c^{2}}{a^{2}}+\frac{b^{2}}{c^{2}}+\frac{8(b+c)}{a}+\frac{2(a+b)}{c}-13 \geq \frac{4 c^{2}}{a^{2}}+\frac{16 c}{a}+\frac{2 a}{c}-10 \geq 2 \sqrt{32}-10>0
\end{array}$$

Consider the following cases:
If $a+c \leq 2 b$, of course $2(b-c) \geq a-c$. If $S_{b} \geq 0$, the inequality is obviously true. Otherwise, assume $S_{b} \leq 0$, then
$$S_{a}(b-c)^{2}+S_{b}(c-a)^{2}+S_{c}(a-b)^{2} \geq\left(S_{a}+4 S_{b}+S_{c}\right)(b-c)^{2} \geq 0$$

If $a+c \geq 2 b$, we will prove $S_{c}+2 S_{b} \geq 0$, i.e.,
$$g(c)=\frac{2 c^{2}}{a^{2}}+\frac{a^{2}}{b^{2}}+\frac{8 b+4 c}{a+b+c}+\frac{4(b+c)}{a}+\frac{2(a+c)}{b}-12 \geq 0$$

Notice that, $g(c)$ is an increasing function for $c \geq 0$ and $c \geq 2 b-a$, so
(.) If $a \geq 2 b$, we have
$$\begin{array}{l}
g(c) \geq g(0)=\frac{a^{2}}{b^{2}}+\frac{8 b}{a+b}+\frac{4 b}{a}+\frac{2 a}{b}-12=\left(\frac{a+b}{b}+\frac{8 b}{a+b}-6\right)+\left(\frac{a}{b}+\frac{4 b}{a}-4\right) \\
+\left(\frac{a^{2}}{b^{2}}-4\right)+\left(\frac{1}{3}-\frac{b}{a+b}\right)+\frac{2}{3} \geq 0
\end{array}$$
(..) If $a \leq 2 b$, we easily get
$$g(c) \geq g(2 b-a)=\frac{8 b^{2}}{a^{2}}+\frac{a^{2}}{b^{2}}+\frac{4 b}{a}-\frac{4 a}{3 b}-\frac{14}{3} \geq 0$$

We thus conclude the proof.
informal_statement: 92. Let $a, b, c$ be any positive real numbers, prove that $\left(a+\frac{b^{2}}{c}\right)^{2}+\left(b+\frac{c^{2}}{a}\right)^{2}+\left(c+\frac{a^{2}}{b}\right)^{2} \geq \frac{12\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)}{a+b+c}$ (Pham Kim Hung)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 92. Let $a, b, c$ be any positive real numbers, prove that $\left(a+\frac{b^{2}}{c}\right)^{2}+\left(b+\frac{c^{2}}{a}\right)^{2}+\left(c+\frac{a^{2}}{b}\right)^{2} \geq \frac{12\left(a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}\right)}{a+b+c}$ (Pham Kim Hung) -/
theorem inequalities_598304
    (a b c : ℝ)
    (ha : 0 < a)
    (hb : 0 < b)
    (hc : 0 < c) :
    (a + b^2 / c)^2 + (b + c^2 / a)^2 + (c + a^2 / b)^2 ≥ 12 * (a^3 + b^3 + c^3) / (a + b + c) := by

soln_description:
2.II.1. The answer follows from a chain of trigonometric transformations:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{tg} 65^{\circ}-2 \operatorname{tg} 40^{\circ}=\operatorname{ctg} 25^{\circ}-2 \operatorname{ctg} 50^{\circ} & =\frac{1}{\operatorname{tg} 25^{\circ}}-\frac{2}{\operatorname{tg} 50^{\circ}}= \\
& =\frac{1}{\operatorname{tg} 25^{\circ}}-\frac{1-\operatorname{tg}^{2} 25^{\circ}}{\operatorname{tg} 25^{\circ}}=\operatorname{tg} 25^{\circ} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Answer: $25^{\circ}$.

soln_description:
Let $y=x$, then we have
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x-y=0, \\
{[x-(-3-2 \sin \theta \cdot \cos \theta)]^{2}+[y-(-a \sin \theta-a \cos \theta)]^{2} \geqslant \frac{1}{8} .}
\end{array}\right.
$$

Thus, the original problem is transformed into considering the square of the distance from the point $(-3-2 \sin \theta \cdot \cos \theta, -a \sin \theta - a \cos \theta)$ to the line $y=x$ being greater than $\frac{1}{8}$ when finding the range of $a$ (where $\theta \in\left[0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right]$).
By the distance formula, we can find that $|-3-2 \sin \theta \cdot \cos \theta + a \sin \theta + a \cos \theta| \geqslant \frac{1}{2}$.
Let $\sin \theta + \cos \theta = t$, then $t = \sqrt{2} \sin \left(\theta + \frac{\pi}{4}\right) \in [1, \sqrt{2}]$.
The original inequality can be transformed into $\left|-3 - (t^2 - 1) + at\right| \geqslant \frac{1}{2}$,
Solving this inequality, we find that $a \geqslant \frac{7}{2}$ or $a \leqslant \sqrt{6}$.
informal_statement: Example 15 (1996 National High School League Question) Find the range of real numbers $a$ such that for any $\theta \in[0$, $\left.\frac{\pi}{2}\right]$, it always holds that $(x+3+2 \sin \theta \cdot \cos \theta)^{2}+(x+a \sin \theta+a \cos \theta)^{2} \geqslant \frac{1}{8}$.

soln_description:
Answer: $(-\infty,-8) \cup(-20 / 3,61 / 8)$.

Solution. Note that $x=0$ is not a solution to the original equation. Therefore, it is equivalent to the equation $a=\frac{-x^{3}-13 x+6}{x^{2}}(*)$. Let's denote the right side by $f(x)$.

Note that $f(x) \xrightarrow{\rightarrow}+\infty$ as $x \rightarrow-\infty$ and $f(x) \rightarrow-\infty$ as $x \rightarrow+\infty$. Also, $f(x)$ has a vertical asymptote at $x=0$.

The derivative of the function $f(x)$ is $f^{\prime}(x)=-\frac{x^{3}-13 x+12}{x^{3}}=-\frac{(x-3)(x-1)(x+4)}{x^{3}}$.

Thus, the function $f(x)$ on the interval $(-\infty,-4]$ decreases from $+\infty$ to $f(-4)=61 / 8$; on the interval $[-4,0)$ - increases from $61 / 8$ to $+\infty$; on the interval $(0,1]-$ decreases from $+\infty$ to $f(1)=-8$; on the interval $[1,3]$ - increases from -8 to $f(3)=-20 / 3$; finally, on the interval $[3,+\infty)-$ decreases from $-20 / 3$ to $-\infty$.

Therefore, each value from the interval ( $-\infty ;-8$ ) is taken by the function $f(x)$ exactly once; -8 - twice; from the interval ( $-8 ;-20 / 3$ ) - three times; $-20 / 3$ - twice; from the interval $(-20 / 3 ; 61 / 8)$ - once; $61 / 8$ - twice; from the interval ( $61 / 8 ;+\infty)$ - three times. (For example, the value -8 will be taken by the function once at the point 1, and the second time - on the interval $(3,+\infty)$ ).

Thus, the equation $\left({ }^{*}\right)$, and with it the original equation, has a unique solution when $a \in(-\infty,-8) \cup(-20 / 3,61 / 8)$.
informal_statement: Problem 8. For what values of the parameter $a$ does the equation $x^{3}+a x^{2}+13 x-6=0$ have a unique solution
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Problem 8. For what values of the parameter $a$ does the equation $x^{3}+a x^{2}+13 x-6=0$ have a unique solution -/
theorem algebra_244789 (a : ℝ) :
    (∃! x : ℝ, x^3 + a * x^2 + 13 * x - 6 = 0) ↔ a < -8 ∨ a > 61 / 8 ∧ a ≠ -20 / 3 := by

soln_description:
2. Since $\sum_{i=1}^{m} a_{i} \geqslant 1+4+\cdots+(3 m-2)=\frac{1}{2}(3 m-1) \cdot m$,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{2} \geqslant 2+5+\cdots+(3 n-1)=\frac{1}{2}(3 n+1) \cdot n, \\
\sum_{i=1}^{k} c_{i} \geqslant 3+6+\cdots+3 k=\frac{1}{2}(3 k+3) \cdot k,
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, $2008 \geqslant \frac{3}{2} \cdot\left(m^{2}-\frac{1}{3} m\right)+\frac{3}{2}\left(n^{2}+\frac{1}{3} n\right)+\frac{3}{2}\left(k^{2}+k\right)$
$$
\begin{array}{c}
\left(m^{2}-\frac{1}{3} m\right)+\left(n^{2}+\frac{1}{3} n\right)+\left(k^{2}+k\right) \leqslant \frac{4014}{3} \\
\left(m-\frac{1}{6}\right)^{2}+\left(n+\frac{1}{6}\right)+\left(k+\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2} \leqslant \frac{48179}{36} \\
\Rightarrow(16+9+25) \cdot \frac{48179}{36} \geqslant\left[\left(4 m-\frac{2}{3}\right)+\left(3 n+\frac{1}{2}\right)+\left(5 k+\frac{5}{2}\right)\right]^{2} \\
=\left(4 m+3 n+5 k+\frac{7}{3}\right)^{2} .
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, $4 m+3 n+5 k \leqslant 256$.
Taking $m=20, n=17, k=25$,
$$
\begin{aligned}
\text { Let } a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{20} & =1,4,7 \cdots 58, \\
b_{1}, b_{2}, \cdots, b_{17} & =2,5,8 \cdots 50, \\
c_{1}, c_{2}, \cdots, c_{25} & =3,6,9 \cdots 75,
\end{aligned}
$$

It is verified to be true.
informal_statement:
II. (50 points)
Let $a_{i} \equiv 1(\bmod 3), 1 \leqslant i \leqslant m, b_{i} \equiv 2(\bmod 3), 1 \leqslant i \leqslant n, c_{i} \equiv 0(\bmod 3), 1 \leqslant i \leqslant$ $k$, and $a_{i}, b_{i}, c_{i}$ these $m+n+k$ numbers are all distinct. If $\sum_{i=1}^{m} a_{i}+\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}+\sum_{i=1}^{k} c_{i}=2007$, find the maximum value of $4 m+3 n+5 k$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- II. (50 points)
Let $a_{i} \equiv 1(\bmod 3), 1 \leqslant i \leqslant m, b_{i} \equiv 2(\bmod 3), 1 \leqslant i \leqslant n, c_{i} \equiv 0(\bmod 3), 1 \leqslant i \leqslant$ $k$, and $a_{i}, b_{i}, c_{i}$ these $m+n+k$ numbers are all distinct. If $\sum_{i=1}^{m} a_{i}+\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}+\sum_{i=1}^{k} c_{i}=2007$, find the maximum value of $4 m+3 n+5 k$. -/
theorem number_theory_278645 (a b c : Finset ℕ) (ha : ∀ i ∈ a, i % 3 = 1)
    (hb : ∀ i ∈ b, i % 3 = 2) (hc : ∀ i ∈ c, i % 3 = 0)
    (hdist : a ∩ b = ∅ ∧ a ∩ c = ∅ ∧ b ∩ c = ∅)
    (hsum : ∑ i ∈ a, i + ∑ i ∈ b, i + ∑ i ∈ c, i = 2007) :
    4 * a.card + 3 * b.card + 5 * c.card ≤ 256 := by

soln_description:

$$
\begin{array}{l}
\quad \frac{1}{\cos 0^{\circ} \cos 1^{\circ}}+\frac{1}{\cos 1^{\circ} \cos 2^{\circ}}+\frac{1}{\cos 2^{\circ} \cos 3^{\circ}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{\cos n^{\circ} \cos (n+1)^{\circ}}=\frac{\tan (n+1)^{\circ}}{\sin 1^{\circ}}(0 \leqslant n \leqslant \\
88, n \in \mathbf{N}) .

$$

Particularly, taking \( n=44 \) and \( n=88 \) yields:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\frac{1}{\cos 0^{\circ} \cos 1^{\circ}}+\frac{1}{\cos 1^{\circ} \cos 2^{\circ}}+\frac{1}{\cos 2^{\circ} \cos 3^{\circ}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{\cos 44^{\circ} \cos 45^{\circ}}=\csc 1^{\circ}, \\
\frac{1}{\cos 0^{\circ} \cos 1^{\circ}}+\frac{1}{\cos 1^{\circ} \cos 2^{\circ}}+\frac{1}{\cos 2^{\circ} \cos 3^{\circ}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{\cos 88^{\circ} \cos 89^{\circ}}=\frac{\cos 1^{\circ}}{\sin ^{2} 1^{\circ}} .

informal_statement: Example $7 \begin{aligned} \tan (n+1)^{\circ}-\tan n^{\circ} & =\frac{\sin (n+1)^{\circ}}{\cos (n+1)^{\circ}}-\frac{\sin n^{\circ}}{\cos n^{\circ}}=\frac{\sin (n+1)^{\circ} \cos n^{\circ}-\cos (n+1)^{\circ} \sin n^{\circ}}{\cos n^{\circ} \cdot \cos (n+1)^{\circ}} \\ & =\frac{\sin 1^{\circ}}{\cos n^{\circ} \cdot \cos (n+1)^{\circ}} .\end{aligned}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example $7 \begin{aligned} \tan (n+1)^{\circ}-\tan n^{\circ} & =\frac{\sin (n+1)^{\circ}}{\cos (n+1)^{\circ}}-\frac{\sin n^{\circ}}{\cos n^{\circ}}=\frac{\sin (n+1)^{\circ} \cos n^{\circ}-\cos (n+1)^{\circ} \sin n^{\circ}}{\cos n^{\circ} \cdot \cos (n+1)^{\circ}} \\ & =\frac{\sin 1^{\circ}}{\cos n^{\circ} \cdot \cos (n+1)^{\circ}} .\end{aligned}$ -/
theorem algebra_160464 (n : ℕ) :
    Real.tan ((n + 1) * Real.pi / 180) - Real.tan (n * Real.pi / 180) =
    Real.sin ((n + 1) * Real.pi / 180) / Real.cos ((n + 1) * Real.pi / 180) -
    Real.sin (n * Real.pi / 180) / Real.cos (n * Real.pi / 180) ∧
    Real.sin ((n + 1) * Real.pi / 180) / Real.cos ((n + 1) * Real.pi / 180) -
    Real.sin (n * Real.pi / 180) / Real.cos (n * Real.pi / 180) =
    Real.sin (Real.pi / 180) / (Real.cos (n * Real.pi / 180) * Real.cos ((n + 1) * Real.pi / 180)) := by

soln_description:
2. When $x<\frac{1}{2}$, $f(x)-x=x^{2}-x<0$; when $x \geqslant \frac{1}{2}$, $f(x)-x=x^{2}-x \geqslant 0$.

Thus, if $a_{k}, b_{k}$ are both in the subinterval $I_{2}$, then
$$
d_{k+2} \geqslant d_{k+1} \geqslant d_{k}\left(1+d_{k}\right) \geqslant d_{k}\left(1+d_{0}\right).
$$

If $a_{k}, b_{k}$ are both in the subinterval $I_{1}$, then $a_{k+1}, b_{k+1}$ are both in the subinterval $I_{2}$.
Hence $d_{k+2} \geqslant d_{k+1}\left(1+d_{k+1}\right)$
$$
\geqslant d_{k+1}\left(1+d_{0}\right) \geqslant d_{k}\left(1+d_{0}\right).
$$

Therefore, in both cases,
$$
d_{k+2} \geqslant d_{k}\left(1+d_{0}\right).
$$

By mathematical induction, for any positive integer $m$, we have
$$
d_{2 m} \geqslant d_{0}\left(1+d_{0}\right)^{m}.
$$

When $m$ is sufficiently large, the right side of inequality (1) is greater than 1, while $a_{2 m}, b_{2 m}$ both belong to $(0,1)$, so $d_{2 m}<1$, a contradiction.

Thus, there exists a positive integer $n$ such that $a_{n-1}, b_{n-1}$ are in different subintervals.
informal_statement:
2. Define the function $f:(0,1) \rightarrow(0,1)$, satisfying
$$
f(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
x+\frac{1}{2}, & x<\frac{1}{2} ; \\
x^{2}, & x \geqslant \frac{1}{2} .
\end{array}\right.
$$

Let positive real numbers $a, b$ satisfy $0<a<b<1$. Define the sequences $\left\{a_{n}\right\}, \left\{b_{n}\right\}$ such that $a_{0}=a, b_{0}=b$, and for any positive integer $n$, we have
$$
a_{n}=f\left(a_{n-1}\right), b_{n}=f\left(b_{n-1}\right) .
$$

Prove: There exists a positive integer $n$, such that
$$
\left(a_{n}-a_{n-1}\right)\left(b_{n}-b_{n-1}\right)<0 .
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open scoped BigOperators

/- 2. Define the function $f:(0,1) \rightarrow(0,1)$, satisfying
$$
f(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
x+\frac{1}{2}, & x<\frac{1}{2} ; \\
x^{2}, & x \geqslant \frac{1}{2} .
\end{array}\right.
$$

Let positive real numbers $a, b$ satisfy $0<a<b<1$. Define the sequences $\left\{a_{n}\right\}, \left\{b_{n}\right\}$ such that $a_{0}=a, b_{0}=b$, and for any positive integer $n$, we have
$$
a_{n}=f\left(a_{n-1}\right), b_{n}=f\left(b_{n-1}\right) .
$$

Prove: There exists a positive integer $n$, such that
$$
\left(a_{n}-a_{n-1}\right)\left(b_{n}-b_{n-1}\right)<0 .
$$ -/
theorem algebra_310946 {f : ℝ → ℝ}
  (hf : ∀ x, x < 1 / 2 → f x = x + 1 / 2)
  (hf' : ∀ x, x ≥ 1 / 2 → f x = x ^ 2)
  (a b : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (h : a < b ∧ b < 1)
  (a_seq b_seq : ℕ → ℝ)
  (h_a0 : a_seq 0 = a)
  (h_b0 : b_seq 0 = b)
  (h_an : ∀ n, a_seq (n + 1) = f (a_seq n))
  (h_bn : ∀ n, b_seq (n + 1) = f (b_seq n)) :
  ∃ n, 0 < n ∧ (a_seq n - a_seq (n - 1)) * (b_seq n - b_seq (n - 1)) < 0 :=

soln_description:
Answer: -2021.

Solution. From the formula

$$
\operatorname{tg}(\alpha-\beta)=\frac{\operatorname{tg} \alpha-\operatorname{tg} \beta}{1+\operatorname{tg} \alpha \cdot \operatorname{tg} \beta}
$$

we express the product of tangents:

$$
\operatorname{tg} \alpha \cdot \operatorname{tg} \beta=\frac{\operatorname{tg} \alpha-\operatorname{tg} \beta}{\operatorname{tg}(\alpha-\beta)}-1
$$

Then

$$
\operatorname{tg} \frac{k \pi}{43} \cdot \operatorname{tg} \frac{(k+1) \pi}{43}=\frac{\operatorname{tg} \frac{(k+1) \pi}{43}-\operatorname{tg} \frac{k \pi}{43}}{\operatorname{tg}\left(\frac{(k+1) \pi}{43}-\frac{k \pi}{43}\right)}-1=\left(\operatorname{tg} \frac{(k+1) \pi}{43}-\operatorname{tg} \frac{k \pi}{43}\right) \cdot\left(\operatorname{tg} \frac{\pi}{43}\right)^{-1}-1
$$

Adding these equalities for all $k$ from 1 to 2019, we get that the expression in the condition equals

$$
\left(\operatorname{tg} \frac{2020 \pi}{43}-\operatorname{tg} \frac{\pi}{43}\right) \cdot\left(\operatorname{tg} \frac{\pi}{43}\right)^{-1}-2019
$$

Notice that

$$
\operatorname{tg} \frac{2020 \pi}{43}=\operatorname{tg}\left(47 \pi-\frac{\pi}{43}\right)=-\operatorname{tg} \frac{\pi}{43}
$$

which means $(*)$ equals -2021.

$$

$$ -/
theorem algebra_241677 : ∑ k : ℕ in Finset.range 2019, tan (π * (k + 1) / 43) * tan (π * (k + 2) / 43) = -2021 := by

$$9 a(a+b)(a+b+c) \geqslant 2(a+\sqrt{a b}+\sqrt[3]{a b c})^{3}$$

Equality holds if and only if $a=b=c$. -/

    9 * a * (a + b) * (a + b + c) ≥ 2 * (a + Real.sqrt (a * b) + (a * b * c) ^ ((1 : ℝ) / 3)) ^ 3 ∧
    (9 * a * (a + b) * (a + b + c) = 2 * (a + Real.sqrt (a * b) + (a * b * c) ^ ((1 : ℝ) / 3)) ^ 3 ↔ a = b ∧ b = c) := by

soln_description:
Answer: February 9.

Let $d(t)$ be the distance to Mars at time $t$. Suppose Mars is at the origin, the probe starts from the point $\left(x_{0}, y_{0}, z_{0}\right)$, and its velocity vector is $\left(v_{x}, v_{y}, v_{z}\right)$.

Then at time $t$, the probe will be at the point $\left(x_{0}+t \cdot v_{x}, y_{0}+t \cdot v_{y}, z_{0}+t \cdot v_{z}\right)$, which is at a distance of $d(t)=\sqrt{\left(\left(x_{0}+t \cdot v_{x}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{0}+t \cdot v_{y}\right)^{2}+\left(z_{0}+t \cdot v_{z}\right)^{2}\right)}$ from Mars. Squaring this, we note that $D(t)=d^{2}(t)$ is a quadratic function of $t$.

Write $D(t)$ in the form $D(t)=a t^{2}+b t+c$ and find the coefficients $a, b, c$.

To simplify the calculations, introduce a time scale $t$ such that the moment $t=0$ corresponds to February 10, then February 1 corresponds to $t=-9$ and February 13 corresponds to $t=3$.

Substitute the known values of the function $D: D(-9)=25, D(0)=4, D(3)=9$ and solve the resulting system:

$$
\left\{\begin{array} { c } 
{ 8 1 a - 9 b + c = 2 5 } \\
{ c = 4 } \\
{ 9 a + 3 b + c = 9 }
\end{array} \Leftrightarrow \left\{\begin{array}{l}
a=\frac{1}{3} \\
b=\frac{2}{3} \\
c=4
\end{array}\right.\right.
$$

Find the vertex of the parabola (the graph of the function $\left.D(t)=\frac{1}{3} t^{2}-\frac{2}{3} t+4\right)$:

This is the point $t_{0}=-\frac{b}{2 a}=-1$, which is the point of minimum of the function $D(t)$, corresponding to February 9.
informal_statement:
6. A space probe, moving in a straight line at a constant speed, flies past Mars and measures the distance to this planet every day at exactly 12:00. It is known that on February 1st, the distance was 5 million km, on February 10th - 2 million km, and on February 13th - 3 million km.

Determine when the probe will pass at the minimum distance from Mars.

In this problem, Mars can be considered a point.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 6. A space probe, moving in a straight line at a constant speed, flies past Mars and measures the distance to this planet every day at exactly 12:00. It is known that on February 1st, the distance was 5 million km, on February 10th - 2 million km, and on February 13th - 3 million km.

Determine when the probe will pass at the minimum distance from Mars.

In this problem, Mars can be considered a point. -/
theorem algebra_190754 (f : ℕ → ℝ) (hf : f 1 = 5000000) (hf' : f 10 = 2000000) (hf'' : f 13 = 3000000) :
    IsLeast {x | ∃ n, x = f n ∧ n ≥ 1} (f 9) := by

informal_statement: Given the parametric equations $x = \frac{4l}{1 + l^2}$ and $y = \frac{2 - 2l^2}{1 + l^2}$, where $l$ is a parameter, determine the range of the function $f(x, y) = x^2 - xy + y^2$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Given the parametric equations $x = \frac{4l}{1 + l^2}$ and $y = \frac{2 - 2l^2}{1 + l^2}$, where $l$ is a parameter, determine the range of the function $f(x, y) = x^2 - xy + y^2$. -/
theorem algebra_5404 (x y : ℝ → ℝ)
  (hx : x = λ l => 4 * l / (1 + l ^ 2))
  (hy : y = λ l => (2 - 2 * l ^ 2) / (1 + l ^ 2)) :
  {z | ∃ l, z = x l ^ 2 - x l * y l + y l ^ 2} = {z | 2 ≤ z ∧ z ≤ 6} :=

informal_statement: Find all values of $k$ for which the angle between the vectors $\begin{pmatrix} k \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ k \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ is $\frac{\pi}{3}.$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Find all values of $k$ for which the angle between the vectors $\begin{pmatrix} k \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ k \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ is $\frac{\pi}{3}.$ -/
theorem calculus_22254 (k : ℝ) :
    arccos ((k * 1 + 1 * k + 1 * 1) / (sqrt (k^2 + 1^2 + 1^2) * sqrt (1^2 + k^2 + 1^2))) = π / 3 ↔
    k = 0 ∨ k = 4 := by

soln_description:
[Proof] Let $M=\left|a_{1}\right|+\left|a_{2}\right|+\cdots+\left|a_{n}\right|$. For a positive integer $k(1 \leqslant k \leqslant n)$, since
$$\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin k x}{\sin x}=k$$

for any $\varepsilon>0$, there exists a real number $x$, such that $\sin x \neq 0$, and
$$\left|\frac{\sin k x}{\sin x}-k\right|<\frac{\varepsilon}{M}, k=1,2, \cdots, n$$

From this, we can obtain
$$\begin{aligned}
1 & \geqslant\left|\frac{f(x)}{\sin x}\right|=\left|\sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{a_{k} \sin k x}{\sin x}\right|=\left|\sum_{k=1}^{n} k a_{k}-\sum_{k=1}^{n}\left(\frac{\sin k x}{\sin x}-k\right) a_{k}\right| \\
& \geqslant\left|\sum_{k=1}^{n} k a_{k}\right|-\sum_{k=1}^{n}\left|\frac{\sin k x}{\sin x}-k\right|\left|a_{k}\right| \geqslant\left|\sum_{k=1}^{n} k a_{k}\right|-\varepsilon,
\end{aligned}$$

By the arbitrariness of $\varepsilon$, the inequality to be proved holds.
informal_statement:
9・178 Let $f(x)=a_{1} \sin x+a_{2} \sin 2 x+\cdots+a_{n} \sin n x$, where $a_{1}$, $a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}$ are real numbers, and $n$ is a positive integer. If for all real numbers $x$ we have
$$|f(x)| \leqslant|\sin x|$$

Prove: $\left|a_{1}+2 a_{2}+\cdots+n a_{n}\right| \leqslant 1$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 9・178 Let $f(x)=a_{1} \sin x+a_{2} \sin 2 x+\cdots+a_{n} \sin n x$, where $a_{1}$, $a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}$ are real numbers, and $n$ is a positive integer. If for all real numbers $x$ we have
$$|f(x)| \leqslant|\sin x|$$

Prove: $\left|a_{1}+2 a_{2}+\cdots+n a_{n}\right| \leqslant 1$. -/
theorem inequalities_602206 {n : ℕ} (hn : 0 < n) (a : ℕ → ℝ)
  (f : ℝ → ℝ) (hf : f = λ x => ∑ i ∈ Finset.range n, a i * sin ((i + 1) * x))
  (h : ∀ x, |f x| ≤ |sin x|) :
  |∑ i ∈ Finset.range n, (i + 1) * a i| ≤ 1 :=

soln_description:
Let the internal resistance of the cells be $r_{b}$, their electromotive force $U_{0}$, and the number of cells connected in series be $s$, while the number of parallel groups be $p$ (see Fig. 1).

# $1987-11-428-1$. eps 

Using Kirchhoff's laws, the current flowing through the external resistance $R$ is:

$$
I_{R}=\frac{p s U_{0}}{p R+s r_{b}}
$$

Using the given data $\left(p s=72, R=36 \Omega, r_{b}=2, U_{0}=4.5 \mathrm{~V}\right)$, we get:

$$
I_{R}=\frac{4.5}{\frac{p}{2}+\frac{2}{p}}
$$

a) The current is maximized when the denominator is minimized under the given conditions. Using the inequality between the arithmetic and geometric means:

$$
\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{p}{2}+\frac{2}{p}\right) \geq \sqrt{1}
$$

The equality condition is: $\frac{p}{2}=\frac{2}{p}=1$, i.e., $p=2$. In this case, we form 2 parallel groups from 36 cells connected in series. The current is $\left.I_{R}^{\max }=2.25 \mathrm{~A} . \mathrm{b}\right)$ The current is minimized when the denominator is maximized under the given conditions. The function $f(p)=\frac{p}{2}+\frac{2}{p}$ is strictly increasing both to the left (smaller $p$ values) and to the right (larger $p$ values) of the previously found minimum point. Therefore, it can achieve its maximum at one of the boundaries of the interval being considered.

For $p=1, \quad I_{R}=1.8 \mathrm{~A}$.

For $p=72, \quad I_{R}=0.125 \mathrm{~A}$.

Thus, the current is minimized when each element is connected in parallel $(s=1)$. The current is $I_{R}^{\min }=0.125 \mathrm{~A}$.

Remarks. 1. Several solvers considered the minimum current to be 0 by connecting the cells in reverse. We did not accept this as a valid solution. If we did not want to create any current, we could obviously achieve this in a much simpler way.

2. Finding the minimum and maximum points using different methods (differentiation, computer) does not result in physically different solutions.
informal_statement:
$72 \mathrm{db} 4.5 \mathrm{~V}$-os, $2 \Omega$ belsó ellenállású zsebtelepet kapcsolunk össze. Hogyan tegyük ezt, hogy az $R=36 \Omega$-os külső ellenálláson folyó áram

a) maximális,

b) minimális legyen?

Mekkorák ezek az áramok? (Csak azokat a kapcsolásokat vegyük figyelembe, amelyek egyenlő számú telepet tartalmazó, sorosan kapcsolt csoportok párhuzamos kapcsolásából állnak.)

$72 \mathrm{db} 4.5 \mathrm{~V}$, $2 \Omega$ internal resistance pocket cells are connected together. How should we do this so that the current flowing through the $R=36 \Omega$ external resistance is

a) maximized,

b) minimized?

What are these currents? (Consider only those connections that consist of parallel-connected groups of cells connected in series, with an equal number of cells in each group.)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- $72 \mathrm{db} 4.5 \mathrm{~V}$-os, $2 \Omega$ belsó ellenállású zsebtelepet kapcsolunk össze. Hogyan tegyük ezt, hogy az $R=36 \Omega$-os külső ellenálláson folyó áram

a) maximális,

b) minimális legyen?

Mekkorák ezek az áramok? (Csak azokat a kapcsolásokat vegyük figyelembe, amelyek egyenlő számú telepet tartalmazó, sorosan kapcsolt csoportok párhuzamos kapcsolásából állnak.)

$72 \mathrm{db} 4.5 \mathrm{~V}$, $2 \Omega$ internal resistance pocket cells are connected together. How should we do this so that the current flowing through the $R=36 \Omega$ external resistance is

a) maximized,

b) minimized?

What are these currents? (Consider only those connections that consist of parallel-connected groups of cells connected in series, with an equal number of cells in each group.) -/
theorem algebra_159109 {I : ℝ → ℝ} (hI : I = fun x => x / (2 * x + 36)) :
    IsGreatest (Set.image I {x | ∃ n, x = n * 2}) (2.25) ∧
    IsLeast (Set.image I {x | ∃ n, x = n * 2}) (0.125) := by

soln_description:
Proof: By making the substitution $a=p^{n}, b=q^{n}, c=r^{n}$, then $a b c=1$, and the original inequality is equivalent to
$$
\frac{1}{a+b+1}+\frac{1}{b+c+1}+\frac{1}{c+a+1} \leqslant 1 .
$$

By the rearrangement inequality
$$
\begin{array}{l}
a+b=a^{\frac{2}{3}} a^{\frac{1}{3}}+b^{\frac{2}{3}} b^{\frac{1}{3}} \geqslant a^{\frac{2}{3}} b^{\frac{1}{3}}+a^{\frac{1}{3}} b^{\frac{2}{3}} . \\
\text { Hence } \frac{1}{a+b+1}=\frac{(a b c)^{\frac{1}{3}}}{(a b c)^{\frac{1}{3}}+a+b} \\
\leqslant \frac{(a b c)^{\frac{1}{3}}}{(a b c)^{\frac{1}{3}}+(a b)^{\frac{1}{3}}\left(a^{\frac{1}{3}}+b^{\frac{1}{3}}\right)} \\
=\frac{c^{\frac{1}{3}}}{a^{\frac{1}{3}}+b^{\frac{1}{3}}+c^{\frac{1}{3}}} .
\end{array}
$$

By cyclically permuting the above inequality and adding them up, we obtain the original inequality.
informal_statement:
Example 1 Let $p, q, r$ be positive numbers, and satisfy $pqr=1$. Prove: for all $n \in \mathbf{N}_{+}$, we have
$$
\frac{1}{p^{n}+q^{n}+1}+\frac{1}{q^{n}+r^{n}+1}+\frac{1}{r^{n}+p^{n}+1} \leqslant 1 \text {. }
$$
(2004, Baltic Region Mathematical Competition)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 1 Let $p, q, r$ be positive numbers, and satisfy $pqr=1$. Prove: for all $n \in \mathbf{N}_{+}$, we have
$$
\frac{1}{p^{n}+q^{n}+1}+\frac{1}{q^{n}+r^{n}+1}+\frac{1}{r^{n}+p^{n}+1} \leqslant 1 \text {. }
$$
(2004, Baltic Region Mathematical Competition) -/
theorem inequalities_317914 (p q r : ℝ) (hpqr : p > 0 ∧ q > 0 ∧ r > 0 ∧ p * q * r = 1)
    (n : ℕ) (hn : n > 0) :
    1 / (p ^ n + q ^ n + 1) + 1 / (q ^ n + r ^ n + 1) +
    1 / (r ^ n + p ^ n + 1) ≤ 1 := by

soln_description:
Solution
B

The origin has coordinates $(0,0)$. Thus it is the point where $x=0$ and $y=0$. It follows that the graph of an equation passes through the origin if the equation shows that $y=0$ when $x=0$.
Now, when $x=0$, the values of $x^{4}+1, x^{4}+x, x^{4}+x^{2}$ and $x^{4}+x^{3}$ are $1,0,0$ and 0 , respectively.
Hence, of the given equations, $y=x^{4}+1$ is the only one whose graph does not pass through the origin.
informal_statement:
11. How many of the following four equations has a graph that does not pass through the origin?
$$
y=x^{4}+1 \quad y=x^{4}+x \quad y=x^{4}+x^{2} \quad y=x^{4}+x^{3}
$$

A 0
B 1
C 2
D 3
E 4
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 11. How many of the following four equations has a graph that does not pass through the origin?
$$
y=x^{4}+1 \quad y=x^{4}+x \quad y=x^{4}+x^{2} \quad y=x^{4}+x^{3}
$$

A 0
B 1
C 2
D 3
E 4 -/
theorem algebra_244009 (f : ℕ → ℝ → ℝ)
    (h₀ : ∀ x, f 0 x = x ^ 4 + 1)
    (h₁ : ∀ x, f 1 x = x ^ 4 + x)
    (h₂ : ∀ x, f 2 x = x ^ 4 + x ^ 2)
    (h₃ : ∀ x, f 3 x = x ^ 4 + x ^ 3) :
    {x | f x 0 ≠ 0}.encard = 1 := by

soln_description:
To show that the function \( f \) has a fixed point in the interval \( (0,1) \), we will use the Intermediate Value Theorem (IVT) and the given conditions.

1. **Given Conditions:**
   - \( f \) is differentiable on \( (-1,2) \).
   - \( f(0) > 0 \).
   - \( f(1) = 1 \).
   - \( f'(1) > 1 \).

2. **Intermediate Value Theorem (IVT):**
   The IVT states that if a function \( g \) is continuous on a closed interval \([a, b]\) and \( g(a) \) and \( g(b) \) have opposite signs, then there exists at least one \( c \in (a, b) \) such that \( g(c) = 0 \).

3. **Define a New Function:**
   Define \( g(x) = f(x) - x \). We need to show that \( g(x) = 0 \) for some \( x \in (0,1) \).

4. **Evaluate \( g \) at the Endpoints:**
   - At \( x = 0 \):
     \[
     g(0) = f(0) - 0 = f(0) > 0
     \]
   - At \( x = 1 \):
     \[
     g(1) = f(1) - 1 = 1 - 1 = 0
     \]

5. **Behavior of \( g \) Near \( x = 1 \):**
   Since \( f'(1) > 1 \), the derivative of \( g \) at \( x = 1 \) is:
   \[
   g'(1) = f'(1) - 1 > 1 - 1 = 0
   \]
   This implies that \( g(x) \) is increasing at \( x = 1 \).

6. **Conclusion Using IVT:**
   - Since \( g(0) > 0 \) and \( g(1) = 0 \), and \( g \) is continuous (as \( f \) is differentiable and hence continuous), by the IVT, there must exist some \( \beta \in (0,1) \) such that:
     \[
     g(\beta) = 0 \implies f(\beta) - \beta = 0 \implies f(\beta) = \beta
     \]

This proves that \( f \) has a fixed point in the interval \( (0,1) \).

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: A real valued function $f$ is defined on the interval $(-1,2)$. A point $x_0$ is said to be a fixed point of $f$ if $f(x_0)=x_0$. Suppose that $f$ is a differentiable function such that $f(0)>0$ and $f(1)=1$. Show that if $f'(1)>1$, then $f$ has a fixed point in the interval $(0,1)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- A real valued function $f$ is defined on the interval $(-1,2)$. A point $x_0$ is said to be a fixed point of $f$ if $f(x_0)=x_0$. Suppose that $f$ is a differentiable function such that $f(0)>0$ and $f(1)=1$. Show that if $f'(1)>1$, then $f$ has a fixed point in the interval $(0,1)$. -/
theorem calculus_70883 {f : ℝ → ℝ}
  (hf : DifferentiableOn ℝ f (Set.Ioo (-1) 2))
  (h0 : f 0 > 0) (h1 : f 1 = 1)
  (h'1 : deriv f 1 > 1) :
  ∃ x ∈ Set.Ioo 0 1, f x = x :=

soln_description:
Theorem 5 Proof: From equations (25) and (41), we have
$$N(n)=4 \sum_{\left.d^{2}\right|_{n}} R\left(\frac{n}{d^{2}}\right)$$

Let $n=n_{1} n_{2},\left(n_{1}, n_{2}\right)=1$. If $d^{2} \mid n$, then there must be $\left(d^{2}, n_{1}\right)=d_{1}^{2}$, $\left(d^{2}, n_{2}\right)=d_{2}^{2}, d=d_{1} d_{2}{ }^{(1)}$; conversely, if $d_{1}^{2}\left|n_{1}, d_{2}^{2}\right| n_{2}, d=d_{1} d_{2}$, then $d^{2} \mid n$. Therefore, when $n=n_{1} n_{2},\left(n_{1}, n_{2}\right)=1$, we have (using Theorem 1 from Chapter 4, §4)
$$\sum_{d^{2} \mid n} R\left(\frac{n}{d^{2}}\right)=\sum_{d_{1}^{2} \mid n_{1}} R\left(\frac{n_{1}}{d_{1}^{2}}\right) \sum_{d_{2}^{2} \mid n_{2}} R\left(\frac{n_{2}}{d_{2}^{2}}\right)$$

Let $n=p_{1}^{\alpha_{1}} \cdots p_{r}^{\alpha_{r}}, p_{j}$ be different primes. From the above equation, we get
$$\sum_{d^{2} \mid} R\left(\frac{n}{d^{2}}\right)=\sum_{d_{1}^{2} \mid p_{1}^{Q_{1}^{1}}} R\left(\frac{p_{1}^{q_{1}^{1}}}{d_{1}^{2}}\right) \cdots \sum_{d_{r}^{2} \mid p_{p}^{\sigma}} R\left(\frac{p_{r}^{\sigma}}{d_{r}^{2}}\right)$$

Let $p$ be a prime, we use Lemma 10 to compute (note equation (46))
$$\sum_{d^{2} \mid p^{a}} R\left(\frac{p^{\alpha}}{d^{2}}\right)=\frac{1}{4} N\left(p^{\alpha}\right)$$

When $p=2$,
$$\frac{1}{4} N\left(2^{a}\right)=R\left(2^{\alpha}\right)+R\left(2^{\sigma-2}\right)+\cdots+R\left(2^{\sigma-2[\sigma / 2]}\right)=1 .$$

When $p \equiv 1(\bmod 4)$,
